2.1 Populations

  • Population set PPP
  • Variates: functions on the individual units u∈Pu\in Pu∈P
  • Population attributes a(P)=f(y1,…,yN)a(P)=f(y_1,\dots, y_N)a(P)=f(y1​,…,yN​) where yiy_iyi​ is a variate value

2.1.1 Population Attributes

  • Indicator function IA(y)={1y∈A0otherwiseI_A(y)=\begin{cases}1&y\in A\\0&\textrm{otherwise}\end{cases}IA​(y)={10​y∈Aotherwise​ where AAA is the set of acceptable variate values.

Location Attributes:

  • Population Average a(P)=yˉ=1N∑y∈Pyu\displaystyle a(P)=\bar{y}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{y\in P}y_ua(P)=yˉ​=N1​y∈P∑​yu​
  • Population Proportion a(P)=1N∑u∈PIA(yu)\displaystyle a(P)=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{u\in P} I_A(y_u)a(P)=N1​u∈P∑​IA​(yu​)
  • Mode
  • Median

Spread Attributes:

  • Population Variance a(P)=1N∑u∈P(yu−yˉ)2\displaystyle a(P)=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{u\in P}(y_u-\bar{y})^2a(P)=N1​u∈P∑​(yu​−yˉ​)2
  • Population Standard Deviation a(P)=SDP(y)=∑u∈P(yu−yˉ)2N\displaystyle a(P)=SD_P(y)=\sqrt{\frac{\sum_{u\in P}(y_u-\bar{y})^2}{N}}a(P)=SDP​(y)=N∑u∈P​(yu​−yˉ​)2​​
  • Coefficient of variation (dimensionless) a(P)=SDP(y)yˉ\displaystyle a(P)=\frac{SD_P(y)}{\bar{y}}a(P)=yˉ​SDP​(y)​
  • Range
  • Inter-Quartile Range (IQR)

Note: the population variance or standard deviation could also be defined using N−1N-1N−1 in the denominator.

Order Statistics: order the variate values yu∈Py_u\in Pyu​∈P from smallest to largest: y(1)≤y(2)≤⋯≤y(N)y_{(1)}\le y_{(2)}\le\cdots\le y_{(N)}y(1)​≤y(2)​≤⋯≤y(N)​.

Location Attributes based on Order Statistics:

  • Population minimum: a(P)=y(1)a(P)=y_{(1)}a(P)=y(1)​
  • Population maximum: a(P)=y(N)a(P)=y_{(N)}a(P)=y(N)​
  • Population mid-range: a(P)=12(y(1)+y(N))a(P)=\frac{1}{2}(y_{(1)}+y_{(N)})a(P)=21​(y(1)​+y(N)​)
  • Population median: a(P)={y([N+1]/2)N is oddy(N/2)+y(N/2+1)2N is evena(P)=\begin{cases}y_{([N+1]/2)}& N\textrm{ is odd}\\\frac{y_{(N/2)}+y_{(N/2+1)}}{2}& N\textrm{ is even}\end{cases}a(P)={y([N+1]/2)​2y(N/2)​+y(N/2+1)​​​N is oddN is even​
  • Population quartiles:
    • Q1Q_1Q1​ is 25th percentile, or the first quartile
    • Q2Q_2Q2​ is 50th percentile, or the median
    • Q3Q_3Q3​ is 75th percentile, or the third quartile

Variability Attributes based on Order Statistics

  • Population range a(P)=y(N)−y(1)a(P)=y_{(N)}-y_{(1)}a(P)=y(N)​−y(1)​
  • Population inter-quantile range IQR: a(P)=Q3−Q1a(P)=Q_3-Q_1a(P)=Q3​−Q1​
  • Median Absolute Deviation (MAD), a measure of center a(P)=medianu∈P∣yu−medianu∈Pyu∣a(P)=\textrm{median}_{u\in P}|y_u-\textrm{median}_{u\in P} y_u|a(P)=medianu∈P​∣yu​−medianu∈P​yu​∣

Skewness Attributes: measure asymmetry in a population, a symmetric distribution should result in skewness attribute of zero.

  • Pearson's moment coefficient of Skewness

    a(P)=1N∑u∈P(yu−yˉ)3[SDP(y)]3\displaystyle a(P)=\frac{\frac{1}{N}\sum_{u\in P}(y_u-\bar{y})^3}{[SD_P(y)]^3} a(P)=[SDP​(y)]3N1​∑u∈P​(yu​−yˉ​)3​

    (note this is dimensionless.)
  • Pearson's second skewness coefficient (median skewness)

    a(P)=3×(yˉ−medianu∈Pyu)SDP(y)a(P)=3\times \frac{(\bar{y}-\textrm{median}_{u\in P}y_u)}{SD_P(y)} a(P)=3×SDP​(y)(yˉ​−medianu∈P​yu​)​

  • Bowley's measure of skewness based on the quartiles:

    a(P)=(Q3+Q1)/2−Q2(Q3−Q1)/2a(P)=\frac{(Q_3+Q_1)/2-Q_2}{(Q_3-Q_1)/2} a(P)=(Q3​−Q1​)/2(Q3​+Q1​)/2−Q2​​

2.2.2 Attribute Properties

Location/Scale/Replication Invariance and Equivariance:

  • location invariance a(y1+b,…,yN+b)=a(P)a(y_1+b,\dots, y_N+b) = a(P)a(y1​+b,…,yN​+b)=a(P)
  • location equivariance a(y1+b,…,yN+b)=a(P)+ba(y_1+b,\dots, y_N+b) = a(P) + ba(y1​+b,…,yN​+b)=a(P)+b
  • scale invariance a(my1,…,myN)=a(P)a(my_1,\dots, my_N)=a(P)a(my1​,…,myN​)=a(P)
  • scale equivariance a(my1,…,myN)=ma(P)a(my_1,\dots, my_N)=ma(P)a(my1​,…,myN​)=ma(P)
  • location-scale invariance: both location invariant and scale invariant
  • location-scale equivariance: both location equivariant and scale equivariant
  • replication invariance: a(Pk)=a(P)a(P^k)=a(P)a(Pk)=a(P) where Pk={y1,…,yN,y1,…,yN,…,y1,…,yN}P^k=\left\{ y_1,\dots, y_N,y_1,\dots, y_N,\dots, y_1,\dots,y_N \right\}Pk={y1​,…,yN​,y1​,…,yN​,…,y1​,…,yN​} of size kNkNkN
  • replication equivariance: a(Pk)=k⋅a(P)a(P^k)=k\cdot a(P)a(Pk)=k⋅a(P)

Population average is location-scale equivariant, and replication invariant

2.2.3 Influence, Sensitivity Curves and Breakdown Points

Influence: the effect that removing unit uuu has on population attribute,

Δ(a,u)=a(P)−a(P\{u})\Delta(a, u)=a(P)-a(P\backslash \{u\}) Δ(a,u)=a(P)−a(P\{u})

Sensitivity Curve: shows the effect of adding a variate to population on attribute.

SC(y,a(P))=N(a(P∪{y})−a(P))SC(y, a(P))=N(a(P\cup\left\{ y \right\})-a(P)) SC(y,a(P))=N(a(P∪{y})−a(P))

Breakdown Points: gives an assessment of just how large a proportion of the data must be contaminated before the statistic breaks down. The breakdown point of a statistic is teh smallest possible fraction of the observations that can be cahnged to something very extreme (plus or minuse infinity) to make the error large (infinite). For example, the break point for

  • Average is 1/N1/N1/N
  • Median is 1/21/21/2, i.e. half of the data has to go to infinity before the median breaks down

Attributes with high breakdown points are called resistant or robust.

2.2.4 Graphical Attributes

Histograms:

  • Partition the range of population into kkk non-overlapping intervals called bins, Ij=[aj−1,aj),j=1,2,…,kI_j=[a_{j-1},a_j), j=1,2,\dots,kIj​=[aj−1​,aj​),j=1,2,…,k and then calculate the number of proportion of observations in the $j$th bin for each jjj.
  • We can define bins two ways
    • Bin of equal size, or
    • bins with equal number of elements by varying size

Rules for the number of bins:

  • Sturge's rule, num of bins should be ⌈log⁡2(N)+1⌉\lceil \log_{2}(N)+1\rceil⌈log2​(N)+1⌉
  • Freedman-Diaconis rule: bin size = 2IQR(x)N1/3\displaystyle 2\frac{\textrm{IQR}(x)}{N^{1/3}}2N1/3IQR(x)​
  • Scott's rule: bin size = 3.5σN1/3\displaystyle 3.5 \frac{\sigma}{N^{1/3}}3.5N1/3σ​

Histograms using different rules for bin size

Scatter-plots:

  • Special note for discreteness, you can
    • Change shading and varying the size of bullets
    • add jitter to population values

2.2.5 Power Transformations

Given variate y>0,y>0,y>0, the general form of power transformation is

Tα(y)={yαα≠0log⁡yα=0T_\alpha(y)=\begin{cases}y^\alpha&\alpha\neq 0\\\log y& \alpha=0\end{cases} Tα​(y)={yαlogy​α=0α=0​

A more convenient form called Box-Cox transformation:

Tα(y)=yα−1α,Note lim⁡α→0Tα(y)=log⁡(y)T_\alpha(y)=\frac{y^\alpha-1}{\alpha},\qquad\textrm{Note }\lim_{\alpha\rightarrow 0} T_\alpha(y)=\log(y) Tα​(y)=αyα−1​,Note α→0lim​Tα​(y)=log(y)

An even more computationally efficient power transformation with minimal potential for calculation errors is the following:

Tα(y)={yαα>0log⁡yα=0−(yα)α<0T_\alpha(y)=\begin{cases}y^\alpha&\alpha> 0\\\log y& \alpha=0\\-(y^\alpha)&\alpha< 0\end{cases} Tα​(y)=⎩⎨⎧​yαlogy−(yα)​α>0α=0α<0​

Bump Rule 1: making histograms more symmetric,

  • if the bump is on the "lower" values, then move the power lower on the ladder
  • if it is on the "higher" values, then move the power higher on the ladder

Bump Rule 2: straightening scatter plots

2.2.6 Order, Rank and Quantiles

Recall we used y(i)y_{(i)}y(i)​ to denote iii'th lowest variate in the population for order statistic and yiy_iyi​ to denote $i$th variate in the population (not ordered).

The Rank Statistics r1,r2,…,rNr_1, r_2,\dots, r_Nr1​,r2​,…,rN​ which is the ranks of the variate values. For example, yi=y(k)y_i=y_{(k)}yi​=y(k)​ is the kth smallest value and so yiy_iyi​ has rank ri=kr_i=kri​=k. This means that (∀u∈P) y(ru)=yu(\forall u\in P)\ y_{(r_u)}=y_u(∀u∈P) y(ru​)​=yu​

Quantiles: rather than using ranks and plot pairs (ru,yu)(r_u, y_u)(ru​,yu​), it can be more convient to use the proportion of units in the population having a value ≤y\le y≤y and plot pairs (pu,yu)(p_u, y_u)(pu​,yu​) where pu=ru/Np_u=r_u/Npu​=ru​/N. Note that

  • The middle value of proportion equal to 1/2 corresopnds to the median
  • The values on the y-axis are the quantiles.

The plotted points are (p,Qy(p))(p, Q_y(p))(p,Qy​(p)) where p∈{1N,2N,…,1}p\in \left\{ \frac{1}{N}, \frac{2}{N},\dots, 1 \right\}p∈{N1​,N2​,…,1} and Qy(p)Q_y(p)Qy​(p) is the pth quantile of y,Qy(p)=y(N×p)y, Q_y(p)=y_{(N\times p)}y,Qy​(p)=y(N×p)​ and is sometimes called the quantile function of yyy for all ppp.

The quantile Qy(p)Q_y(p)Qy​(p) for any ppp locates the variate values in the population and is thus a measure of location. Most but not all location measures try ot capture central tendency.

Quantiles that measure center:

  • Median Qy(1/2)Q_y(1/2)Qy​(1/2)
  • Mid-hinge (average of the first and third quartiles) Qy(1/4)+Qy(3/4)2\frac{Q_y(1/4)+Q_y(3/4)}{2}2Qy​(1/4)+Qy​(3/4)​
  • Mid-range (average of minimum and maximum): Qy(1/N)+Qy(1)2\frac{Q_y(1/N)+Q_y(1)}{2}2Qy​(1/N)+Qy​(1)​
  • Trimean: Qy(1/4)+2Qy(1/2)+Qy(3/4)4\frac{Q_y(1/4)+2 Q_y(1/2)+Q_y(3/4)}{4}4Qy​(1/4)+2Qy​(1/2)+Qy​(3/4)​

Quantiles that measure spread:

  • Range Qy(1)−Qy(1/N)Q_y(1)-Q_y(1/N)Qy​(1)−Qy​(1/N)
  • Inter-quartile range IQRy=Qy(3/4)−Qy(1/4)IQR_y=Q_y(3/4)-Q_y(1/4)IQRy​=Qy​(3/4)−Qy​(1/4)
  • Central 100 ×p%\times p\%×p% range
  • Alternatively, the slope of the line segment joining any two points (p1,Qy(p1))(p_1, Q_y(p_1))(p1​,Qy​(p1​)) and (p2,Qy(p2))(p_2, Q_y(p_2))(p2​,Qy​(p2​)) for p1<p2p_1<p_2p1​<p2​ provides a measure of spread.

Concentration in Quantile Plots:

drawing a box with fixed height and see how many elements are within the box, and we get a histogram!! Note that the width of the box is proportional to the number of elements it contains.

2.3.1a Implicitly Defined Attributes

We are interested in a (possibly vector-valued) attribute θ\thetaθ which minimizes some function ρ(θ;P)\rho(\theta; P)ρ(θ;P) of the variates in the population. Notation, we want the value θ^=arg min⁡θ∈Θρ(θ;P)\displaystyle \hat{\theta}=\argmin_{\theta\in \Theta}\rho(\theta; P)θ^=θ∈Θargmin​ρ(θ;P), where Θ\ThetaΘ is the parameter space.

The most common form for ρ(θ,P)\rho(\theta,P)ρ(θ,P) is the sum of functions ρ(θ,u)\rho(\theta, u)ρ(θ,u) evaluated at each unit u∈Pu\in Pu∈P

ρ(θ;P)=∑u∈Pρ(θ,u)\rho(\theta;P)=\sum_{u\in P}\rho(\theta, u) ρ(θ;P)=u∈P∑​ρ(θ,u)

Important examples:

  • Least squares ρ(θ,u)=(yu−θ)2  ⟹  θ^=yˉ\rho(\theta, u)=(y_u-\theta)^2\implies \hat{\theta}=\bar{y}ρ(θ,u)=(yu​−θ)2⟹θ^=yˉ​
  • Weighted least-squares ρ(θ,u)=wu(yu−θ)2  ⟹  θ^=∑wuyu∑wu\rho(\theta, u)=w_u(y_u-\theta)^2\implies\hat{\theta}=\frac{\sum w_u y_u}{\sum w_u}ρ(θ,u)=wu​(yu​−θ)2⟹θ^=∑wu​∑wu​yu​​
  • Least absolute deviations ρ(θ;u)=∣yu−θ∣  ⟹  θ^=Qy(1/2)\rho(\theta;u)=|y_u-\theta|\implies \hat{\theta}=Q_y(1/2)ρ(θ;u)=∣yu​−θ∣⟹θ^=Qy​(1/2), median
  • Least generalized-absolute deviations: if for some q∈(0,1)q\in (0,1)q∈(0,1) we define the vee function

    ρq(θ,u)={q(yu−θ)yu≥θ(q−1)(yu−θ)yu<θ  ⟹  θ^=Qy(q)\rho_q(\theta,u)=\begin{cases}q(y_u-\theta)&y_u\ge \theta\\(q-1)(y_u-\theta)&y_u<\theta\end{cases}\implies \hat{\theta}=Q_y(q) ρq​(θ,u)={q(yu​−θ)(q−1)(yu​−θ)​yu​≥θyu​<θ​⟹θ^=Qy​(q)

Linear Regression, yu=α+β(xu−c)+ruy_u=\alpha+\beta(x_u-c)+r_uyu​=α+β(xu​−c)+ru​ for some u∈P≔{(x1,y1),(x2,y2),…,(xN,yN)}u\in P\coloneqq\left\{ (x_1,y_1),(x_2, y_2),\dots, (x_N, y_N) \right\}u∈P:={(x1​,y1​),(x2​,y2​),…,(xN​,yN​)}. The attribute of interest is θ=(α,β)\theta=(\alpha, \beta)θ=(α,β).

Note that re-centering of the xux_uxu​ values in a linear regression is not uncommon, typically c=xˉc=\bar{x}c=xˉ, for example.

Those coefficients are determined implicitly by

θ^=(α^,β^)=arg min⁡(α,β)∈R2∑u∈P[yu−(α+β(xu−c))]2\hat{\theta}=(\hat{\alpha},\hat{\beta})=\argmin_{(\alpha,\beta)\in \mathbb{R}^2} \sum_{u\in P}[y_u-(\alpha+\beta(x_u-c))]^2 θ^=(α^,β^​)=(α,β)∈R2argmin​u∈P∑​[yu​−(α+β(xu​−c))]2

It can be shown that α^=yˉ−β^(xˉ−c)\hat{\alpha}=\bar{y}-\hat{\beta}(\bar{x}-c)α^=yˉ​−β^​(xˉ−c) and

β^=∑u∈P(xu−xˉ)(yu−yˉ)∑u∈P(xu−xˉ)2\hat{\beta}=\frac{\sum_{u\in P}(x_u-\bar{x})(y_u-\bar{y})}{\sum_{u\in P}(x_u-\bar{x})^2} β^​=∑u∈P​(xu​−xˉ)2∑u∈P​(xu​−xˉ)(yu​−yˉ​)​

Resulting in least-squares fitted line y=α^+β^(x−c)y=\hat{\alpha}+\hat{\beta}(x-c)y=α^+β^​(x−c). The residuals for each individual unit is r^u=yu−α^−β^(xu−c)\hat{r}_u=y_u-\hat{\alpha}-\hat{\beta}(x_u-c)r^u​=yu​−α^−β^​(xu​−c).

Influence is relevant with implicitly defined attributes. For vector valued attributes, we could have measure of distance (i.e. a different norm).

2.3.1b Robust Regression

Consider the case where the minority of the population has extreme values.

Method 1: remove influential units.

Method 2: weighted linear regression

(α^,β^)=arg min⁡(α,β)∈R2∑u∈Pwu[yu−α−β(xu−c)](\hat{\alpha},\hat{\beta})=\argmin_{(\alpha, \beta)\in \mathbb{R}^2} \sum_{u\in P}w_u[y_u-\alpha-\beta(x_u-c)] (α^,β^​)=(α,β)∈R2argmin​u∈P∑​wu​[yu​−α−β(xu​−c)]

In this setting, set c=0c=0c=0 or define ccc to be the weighted average of xux_uxu​ values.

It can be shown that α^=yˉw−β^(xˉw−c)\hat{\alpha}=\bar{y}_w-\hat{\beta}(\bar{x}_w-c)α^=yˉ​w​−β^​(xˉw​−c) and

β^=∑u∈Pwu(xu−xˉw)(yu−yˉw)∑u∈Pwu(xu−xˉw)2\hat{\beta}=\frac{\sum_{u\in P}w_u(x_u-\bar{x}_w)(y_u-\bar{y}_w)}{\sum_{u\in P}w_u(x_u-\bar{x}_w)^2} β^​=∑u∈P​wu​(xu​−xˉw​)2∑u∈P​wu​(xu​−xˉw​)(yu​−yˉ​w​)​

where yˉw=∑wuyu∑wu,xˉw\bar{y}_w=\frac{\sum w_u y_u}{\sum w_u}, \bar{x}_wyˉ​w​=∑wu​∑wu​yu​​,xˉw​ are weighted averages of y,xy,xy,x.

A common way to select weight is by

  1. Find outlier units
  2. Compute regular regression and the residuals
  3. Compute outlier residual standard deviation, as well as remaining residual standard deviation
  4. Take the ratio and assign the weight (much smaller than 1) to the outliers, while weight for remaining is 1.

Both deletion and reweighting are very manual, we move on to more automatic procedure.

Method 3: Robust Regression - Huber

(α^,β^)=arg min⁡(α,β)∈R2∑u∈Pρ(yu−α−β(xu−c))(\hat{\alpha},\hat{\beta})=\argmin_{(\alpha, \beta)\in \mathbb{R}^2} \sum_{u\in P} \rho (y_u-\alpha-\beta(x_u-c)) (α^,β^​)=(α,β)∈R2argmin​u∈P∑​ρ(yu​−α−β(xu​−c))

where we use Huber Loss Function ρ≔ρk\rho\coloneqq \rho_kρ:=ρk​ with hyperparameter kkk that gives lower weight than least squares to units with large residuals (∣ru∣≫0)(|r_u|\gg 0)(∣ru​∣≫0) and behaves similarly to LS for units with small residuals (∣ru∣≈0)(|r_u|\approx 0)(∣ru​∣≈0).

ρk(r)={12r2∣r∣≤kk∣r∣−12k2∣r∣>k\rho_k(r)=\begin{cases} \frac{1}{2}r^2 & |r|\le k\\ k|r|-\frac{1}{2}k^2 & |r|>k \end{cases}ρk​(r)={21​r2k∣r∣−21​k2​∣r∣≤k∣r∣>k​

Common choices are k=1.5k=1.5k=1.5 or 222. As kkk increases, the robust regression with Huber function imposes a larger penalty on larger residuals, hence approaches the least square fit.

Method 4: Robust Regression - least absolute deviations (LAD)

(α^,β^)=arg min⁡(α,β)∈R2∑u∈P∣yu−α−β(xu−c)∣(\hat{\alpha},\hat{\beta})=\argmin_{(\alpha, \beta)\in \mathbb{R}^2} \sum_{u\in P} |y_u-\alpha-\beta(x_u-c)| (α^,β^​)=(α,β)∈R2argmin​u∈P∑​∣yu​−α−β(xu​−c)∣

Note that in neither Huber nor LAD-based regression can we find a closed form expression for (α^,β^)(\hat{\alpha}, \hat{\beta})(α^,β^​). So we need numerical methods: gradient descent, Newton-Raphson and iteratively reweighted least squares.

2.3.2a Gradient Descent

Given objective function θ^=arg min⁡θ∈Θρ(θ;P)\displaystyle \hat{\theta}=\argmin_{\theta\in \Theta}\rho(\theta; P)θ^=θ∈Θargmin​ρ(θ;P). Provided ρ\rhoρ is differentiable and θ∈Rk\theta\in \mathbb{R}^kθ∈Rk, gradient is defined as

g=g(θ)=∇ρ(θ;P)=[∂ρ∂θ1⋮∂ρ∂θk]g=g(\theta)=\nabla\rho(\theta;P)=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{\partial \rho}{\partial \theta_1}\\ \vdots\\ \frac{\partial \rho}{\partial \theta_k} \end{bmatrix}g=g(θ)=∇ρ(θ;P)=⎣⎡​∂θ1​∂ρ​⋮∂θk​∂ρ​​⎦⎤​

At iteration iii we have best guess θ^i\hat{\theta}_iθ^i​ and we denote the gradient as well as its normalized direction as

gi=g(θ^i)di=gi∥gi∥2g_i=g(\hat{\theta}_i)\qquad d_i=\frac{g_i}{\|g_i\|_2} gi​=g(θ^i​)di​=∥gi​∥2​gi​​

  • did_idi​ indicates the direction of steepest ascent
  • −di-d_i−di​ indictes the direction of steepest descent

Choosing step size λ\lambdaλ at each iteration:

  1. Choose a fixed value for all iii, e.g. λi=0.1\lambda_i=0.1λi​=0.1 as learning rate
  2. Define a fixed sequence, e.g. λi=0.1+1/i\lambda_i=0.1+1/iλi​=0.1+1/i
  3. Perform a line search and algorithmically pick value of λi\lambda_iλi​ that minimizes ρ(θ^i−λidi)\rho(\hat{\theta}_i-\lambda_i d_i)ρ(θ^i​−λi​di​), see below

Gradient Descent Algorithm: given some initial value θ^0\hat{\theta}_0θ^0​

  1. Initialize i←0i\leftarrow 0i←0
  2. Loop:
    1. Gradient: gi=∇ρ(θ;P)∣θ=θ^ig_i=\nabla \rho(\theta;P)|_{\theta=\hat{\theta}_i}gi​=∇ρ(θ;P)∣θ=θ^i​​
    2. Gradient direction: di=gi/∥gi∥2d_i=g_i/\|g_i\|_2di​=gi​/∥gi​∥2​
    3. Line search: λ^i=arg min⁡λ>0ρ(θ^i−λdi)\displaystyle \hat{\lambda}_i=\argmin_{\lambda>0} \rho(\hat{\theta}_i-\lambda d_i)λ^i​=λ>0argmin​ρ(θ^i​−λdi​)
    4. Update the iterate θ^i+1=θ^i−λ^i⋅di\hat{\theta}_{i+1}=\hat{\theta}_i-\hat{\lambda}_i\cdot d_iθ^i+1​=θ^i​−λ^i​⋅di​
    5. Converged? θ^i\hat{\theta}_iθ^i​ vs θ^i+1\hat{\theta}_{i+1}θ^i+1​ or ρ(θ^i)\rho(\hat{\theta}_i)ρ(θ^i​) vs ρ(θ^i+1)\rho(\hat{\theta}_{i+1})ρ(θ^i+1​)
      • If the iterates are not changing, return
      • Else i←i+1i\leftarrow i+1i←i+1 and repeat LOOP
  3. Return θ^=θ^i\hat{\theta}=\hat{\theta}_iθ^=θ^i​

2.3.2b Gradient Descent Robust Regression Example

Main takeaways:

  • Avoiding reliance on global environment inside function.
  • Functions containing their own data environment are called closures.
    • Every function has a local environment where variables may be defined; this is hte closre of the function.
    • Functions also have access to the environment in which they were created
    • We exploit this property by creating functions that themselves define and return a function, so that the returned closure has access to any variables defined within the enclosing function that defined it. In other words, we create factory function that make functions.
  • Encapsulation of data within a function is an important and power construct.

Tips on gradient computation: use chain rule, e.g.

g=∇ρ(θ)=∂∂θ∑u∈Pρk(ru)=∑u∈P∂ρk(ru)∂ru×∂ru∂θg=\nabla\rho(\theta)=\frac{\partial}{\partial \theta}\sum_{u\in P} \rho_k(r_u)=\sum_{u\in P}\frac{\partial \rho_k(r_u)}{\partial r_u}\times\frac{\partial r_u}{\partial \theta} g=∇ρ(θ)=∂θ∂​u∈P∑​ρk​(ru​)=u∈P∑​∂ru​∂ρk​(ru​)​×∂θ∂ru​​

Then it suffices to compute ∂ρk(ru)∂ru\frac{\partial \rho_k(r_u)}{\partial r_u}∂ru​∂ρk​(ru​)​ and ∂ru∂θ\frac{\partial r_u}{\partial \theta}∂θ∂ru​​.

2.3.2c Batch Gradient Descent

In the case ρ(θ;P)=∑u∈Pρ(θ;u)\rho(\theta;P)=\sum_{u\in P}\rho(\theta;u)ρ(θ;P)=∑u∈P​ρ(θ;u) and g(θ)=∇ρ(θ;P)=∑u∈Pg(θ;u)g(\theta)=\nabla\rho(\theta;P)=\sum_{u\in P}g(\theta;u)g(θ)=∇ρ(θ;P)=∑u∈P​g(θ;u),

  • The gradient ggg is composed of NNN smaller independent gradient calculations
  • These individual gradient calculations g(θ;u)g(\theta;u)g(θ;u) can be done in any order.
  • We can use batch gradient descent, where we explicitly partition the population PPP into HHH non-overlapping batches P=B1∪B2∪⋯∪BHP=B_1\cup B_2\cup\cdots\cup B_HP=B1​∪B2​∪⋯∪BH​, each containing μk\mu_kμk​ units k=1,…,Hk=1,\dots, Hk=1,…,H. Then

    g=∑u∈Pg(θ;u)=∑k=1H∑u∈Bkg(θ;u)g=\sum_{u\in P}g(\theta;u)=\sum_{k=1}^H \sum_{u\in B_k}g(\theta;u) g=u∈P∑​g(θ;u)=k=1∑H​u∈Bk​∑​g(θ;u)

Batch gradient descent lends itself well to parallel computation, but what if the gradient calculations are sufficiently complex and even parallelization is not fast enough?

Gradient descent using subsets of the population:

  • This yields an estimation of actual gradient.
  • In such situations we typically do not optimize for the step size λ\lambdaλ and instead use a fixed step size λ∗\lambda^*λ∗ referred to as the learning rate.
  • Two common approaches to do this are batch-sequential and batch-stochastic gradient descent.

Batch sequential gradient descent algorithm: Divide the population of size NNN to HHH batches of size MMM s.t. N=HMN=HMN=HM and P={B1,…,BH}P=\left\{ B_1,\dots, B_H \right\}P={B1​,…,BH​}. Given some initial value θ^0\hat{\theta}_0θ^0​ and a fixed step size λ∗\lambda^*λ∗,

  1. Initialize i←0i\leftarrow 0i←0
  2. Loop:
    1. Gradient: gi=∇ρ(θ;Bi(modH))∣θ=θ^ig_i=\nabla \rho(\theta; B_{i\pmod{H}})|_{\theta=\hat{\theta}_i}gi​=∇ρ(θ;Bi(modH)​)∣θ=θ^i​​
    2. Gradient direction: di=gi/∥gi∥2d_i=g_i/\|g_i\|_2di​=gi​/∥gi​∥2​
    3. Update the iterate θ^i+1=θ^i−λ∗⋅di\hat{\theta}_{i+1}=\hat{\theta}_i-\lambda^*\cdot d_iθ^i+1​=θ^i​−λ∗⋅di​
    4. Converged?
      • If the iterates are not changing, return
      • Else i←i+1i\leftarrow i+1i←i+1 and repeat LOOP
  3. Return θ^=θ^i\hat{\theta}=\hat{\theta}_iθ^=θ^i​

Batch-stochastic gradient descent (stochastic gradient descent for short) algorithm: each iteration of the gradient is calculated from a sample (batch) SSS selected randomly from the population PPP. Given some initial value θ^0\hat{\theta}_0θ^0​ and a fixed step size λ∗\lambda^*λ∗,

  1. Initialize i←0i\leftarrow 0i←0
  2. Loop:
    1. Gradient: gi=∇ρ(θ;Bi(modH))∣θ=θ^ig_i=\nabla \rho(\theta; B_{i\pmod{H}})|_{\theta=\hat{\theta}_i}gi​=∇ρ(θ;Bi(modH)​)∣θ=θ^i​​
    2. Gradient direction: di=gi/∥gi∥2d_i=g_i/\|g_i\|_2di​=gi​/∥gi​∥2​
    3. Update the iterate θ^i+1=θ^i−λ∗⋅di\hat{\theta}_{i+1}=\hat{\theta}_i-\lambda^*\cdot d_iθ^i+1​=θ^i​−λ∗⋅di​
    4. Converged?
      • If the iterates are not changing, return
      • Else i←i+1i\leftarrow i+1i←i+1 and repeat LOOP
  3. Return θ^=θ^i\hat{\theta}=\hat{\theta}_iθ^=θ^i​

2.3.3a Systems of Equations

Given an implicit attribute θ\thetaθ defined as θ^=arg min⁡θ∈Θρ(θ;P)\hat{\theta}=\argmin_{\theta\in \Theta}\rho(\theta;P)θ^=argminθ∈Θ​ρ(θ;P). We can obtain the solution by solving

∇ρ(θ;P)=0\nabla \rho(\theta;P)=0 ∇ρ(θ;P)=0

We define a more general class of implicit attribute θ\thetaθ, defined as

ψ(θ;P)=0\psi (\theta;P)=0 ψ(θ;P)=0

Often, we have ψ(θ;P)=∑u∈Pψ(θ;u)\displaystyle \psi(\theta;P)=\sum_{u\in P}\psi(\theta;u)ψ(θ;P)=u∈P∑​ψ(θ;u). This will be the assumption of the following sections. We now venture into the territory of numerical methods.

Newton's Method: suppose we have scalar attribute θ\thetaθ and wish to find θ∈Θ\theta\in \Thetaθ∈Θ such that ψ(θ;P)=0\psi(\theta;P)=0ψ(θ;P)=0.

Given an initial value θ^0\hat{\theta}_0θ^0​,

  1. Initialize i←0i\leftarrow 0i←0
  2. Loop:
    1. Update the iterate θ^i+1=θ^i−ψ(θ^i;P)ψ′(θ^i;P)\hat{\theta}_{i+1}=\hat{\theta}_i-\frac{\psi(\hat{\theta}_i;P)}{\psi'(\hat{\theta}_i;P)}θ^i+1​=θ^i​−ψ′(θ^i​;P)ψ(θ^i​;P)​
    2. Converged?
      • If the iterates are not changing, return
      • Else i←i+1i\leftarrow i+1i←i+1 and repeat LOOP
  3. Return θ^=θ^i\hat{\theta}=\hat{\theta}_iθ^=θ^i​

Note this algorithm converges in 2 iterations if ψ\psiψ is a linear function of θ\thetaθ.

2.3.3b Newton-Raphson Method

This is the multivariate analog to Newton's Method. When θ=(θ1,…,θk)\theta=(\theta_1,\dots,\theta_k)θ=(θ1​,…,θk​) is a vector-valued attribute, and we want to solve ψ(θ;P)=0⃗\psi(\theta;P)=\vec{0}ψ(θ;P)=0 (system of kkk equations). Note that ψ(θ;P)\psi(\theta;P)ψ(θ;P) is a differentiable k×1k\times 1k×1 vector (ψ1,ψ2,…,ψk)(\psi_1,\psi_2,\dots, \psi_k)(ψ1​,ψ2​,…,ψk​)

The "derivative" is now the Jacobian matrix of ψ\psiψ,

ψ′(θ;P)=∂ψ(θ;P)∂θ=[∂ψ1∂θ1∂ψ1∂θ2⋯∂ψ1∂θk∂ψ2∂θ1∂ψ2∂θ2⋯∂ψ2∂θk⋮⋮⋱⋮∂ψk∂θ1∂ψk∂θ2⋯∂ψk∂θk]\psi'(\theta;P)=\frac{\partial \psi(\theta;P)}{\partial \theta}=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{\partial \psi_1}{\partial \theta_1} & \frac{\partial \psi_1}{\partial \theta_2} &\cdots & \frac{\partial \psi_1}{\partial \theta_k}\\ \frac{\partial \psi_2}{\partial \theta_1} & \frac{\partial \psi_2}{\partial \theta_2} &\cdots & \frac{\partial \psi_2}{\partial \theta_k}\\ \vdots&\vdots&\ddots&\vdots\\ \frac{\partial \psi_k}{\partial \theta_1} & \frac{\partial \psi_k}{\partial \theta_2} &\cdots & \frac{\partial \psi_k}{\partial \theta_k}\\ \end{bmatrix}ψ′(θ;P)=∂θ∂ψ(θ;P)​=⎣⎡​∂θ1​∂ψ1​​∂θ1​∂ψ2​​⋮∂θ1​∂ψk​​​∂θ2​∂ψ1​​∂θ2​∂ψ2​​⋮∂θ2​∂ψk​​​⋯⋯⋱⋯​∂θk​∂ψ1​​∂θk​∂ψ2​​⋮∂θk​∂ψk​​​⎦⎤​

Note that ψ(θ)≈ψ(θ^)+ψ′(θ^)×(θ−θ^)\psi (\theta)\approx\psi(\hat{\theta})+\psi'(\hat{\theta})\times(\theta-\hat{\theta})ψ(θ)≈ψ(θ^)+ψ′(θ^)×(θ−θ^), which is rearranged for the algorithm.

Newton-Raphson Algorithm: given an initial value θ^0\hat{\theta}_0θ^0​

  1. Initialize i←0i\leftarrow 0i←0
  2. Loop:
    1. Update the iterate θ^i+1=θ^i−[ψ′(θ^i;P)]−1 ψ(θ^i;P)\hat{\theta}_{i+1}=\hat{\theta}_i-[\psi'(\hat{\theta}_i;P)]^{-1}\ \psi(\hat{\theta}_i; P)θ^i+1​=θ^i​−[ψ′(θ^i​;P)]−1 ψ(θ^i​;P)
    2. Converged?
      • If the iterates are not changing, return
      • Else i←i+1i\leftarrow i+1i←i+1 and repeat LOOP
  3. Return θ^=θ^i\hat{\theta}=\hat{\theta}_iθ^=θ^i​

Note that we don't actually compute the inverse of the Jacobian, we solve the system of equation [ψ′(θ^i;P)]x=ψ(θ^;P)[\psi'(\hat{\theta}_i;P)]x=\psi(\hat{\theta};P)[ψ′(θ^i​;P)]x=ψ(θ^;P) instead for xxx, and then get θ^i+1\hat{\theta}_{i+1}θ^i+1​ from xxx.

Connection between Newton-Raphson and Gradient Descent: Apply Newton-Raphson to find implicit attribute, where ψ≔∇ρ\psi\coloneqq \nabla\rhoψ:=∇ρ. Substitute and we found

θ^i+1=θ^i−H−1gi\hat{\theta}_{i+1}=\hat{\theta}_i-H^{-1}g_i θ^i+1​=θ^i​−H−1gi​

where HHH is the hessian matrix. Thus Newton-Raphson applied to the gradient of the objective function is essentially equivalent to gradient descent applied directly to the objective function but with step sizes modulated by the Hessian of the objective function.

2.3.4a Iteratively Reweighted Least Squares (IRLS)

We go back to general regression problem of the form (α^,β^)=arg min⁡(α,β)∈R2∑u∈Pρ(yu−α−β(xu−c))\displaystyle (\hat{\alpha},\hat{\beta})=\argmin_{(\alpha, \beta)\in \mathbb{R}^2} \sum_{u\in P} \rho (y_u-\alpha-\beta(x_u-c))(α^,β^​)=(α,β)∈R2argmin​u∈P∑​ρ(yu​−α−β(xu​−c)). Differentiating w.r.t. α\alphaα and β\betaβ yields

∑u∈Pρ′(yu−α−β(xu−c))[1xu−c]=0\sum_{u\in P}\rho'(y_u-\alpha-\beta(x_u-c))\begin{bmatrix}1\\x_u-c\end{bmatrix}=0 u∈P∑​ρ′(yu​−α−β(xu​−c))[1xu​−c​]=0

and θ^=(α^,β^)\hat{\theta}=(\hat{\alpha},\hat{\beta})θ^=(α^,β^​) is found by solving this system of equations. If we let ru=yu−α−β(xu−c)r_u=y_u-\alpha-\beta(x_u-c)ru​=yu​−α−β(xu​−c) and zu=(1,xu−c)z_u=(1,x_u-c)zu​=(1,xu​−c), then the system can be written to look like weighted linear square (WLS) form

0=∑u∈Pρ′(ru)⋅zu=∑u∈P(ρ′(ru)ru)⋅ru⋅zu=∑u∈Pwu⋅ru⋅zu\begin{aligned} 0&=\sum_{u\in P}\rho'(r_u)\cdot z_u\\ &=\sum_{u\in P} \left( \frac{\rho'(r_u)}{r_u} \right) \cdot r_u\cdot z_u\\ &=\sum_{u\in P} w_u \cdot r_u\cdot z_u\\ \end{aligned}0​=u∈P∑​ρ′(ru​)⋅zu​=u∈P∑​(ru​ρ′(ru​)​)⋅ru​⋅zu​=u∈P∑​wu​⋅ru​⋅zu​​

That is, we find weight wu=ρ′(ru)ruw_u= \frac{\rho'(r_u)}{r_u}wu​=ru​ρ′(ru​)​ for unit uuu provided ru≠0r_u\neq 0ru​=0. Why did we do this? because WLC has a closed form solution!!

The idea is we calculate the residuals from the guesses of each iteration, transform the problem into WLC which yields the best guess for next iteration.

Iteratively Reweighted Least Squares Algorithm: given an initial value θ^0\hat{\theta}_0θ^0​

  1. Initialize i←0i\leftarrow 0i←0
  2. Loop:
    1. Construct residuals and weights for all u∈Pu\in Pu∈P:

      ru=yu−zu⊺θ^iwu=ρ′(ru)ruzu=[1xu−c]r_u=y_u-z_u^\intercal \hat{\theta}_i\quad w_u=\frac{\rho'(r_u)}{r_u}\quad z_u= \begin{bmatrix} 1\\x_u-c\end{bmatrix} ru​=yu​−zu⊺​θ^i​wu​=ru​ρ′(ru​)​zu​=[1xu​−c​]

    2. Solve the least squares problem, i.e. find θ^\hat{\theta}θ^ s.t. ∑u∈Pwu(yu−zu⊺θ)zu=0\sum_{u\in P}w_u(y_u-z_u^\intercal\theta)z_u=0∑u∈P​wu​(yu​−zu⊺​θ)zu​=0
    3. Update the iparameter: θ^i+1=θ^\hat{\theta}_{i+1}=\hat{\theta}θ^i+1​=θ^
    4. Converged?
      • If the iterates are not changing, return
      • Else i←i+1i\leftarrow i+1i←i+1 and repeat LOOP
  3. Return θ^=θ^i\hat{\theta}=\hat{\theta}_iθ^=θ^i​

The algorithm above works for any vector-valued attribute θ\thetaθ that arises in the context of a linear response model yu=zu⊺θ+ruy_u=z_u^\intercal \theta + r_uyu​=zu⊺​θ+ru​.

3.0 Samples

Consider sample S\mathcal{S}S of n≪Nn\ll Nn≪N units. The attribute a(S)=a^(P)a(\mathcal{S})=\hat{a}(\mathcal{P})a(S)=a^(P) is an estimate of its population counterpart a(P)a(\mathcal{P})a(P).

When using a sample instead of the entire population, we might consider

  • Sample error: a(S)−a(P)a(\mathcal{S})-a(\mathcal{P})a(S)−a(P)
  • Fisher consistency: if S=P\mathcal{S}=\mathcal{P}S=P then the sample error should be zero.

3.1 All Possible Samples

Suppose population P\mathcal{P}P was of size NNN and that the sample S\mathcal{S}S was of size nnn. Then there are (Nn){N\choose n}(nN​) different possible samples S\mathcal{S}S of size nnn.

For every sample we can calculate any attribute. The average sample error over all possible samples of size nnn is

1NS∑i=1NS[a(Si)−a(P)]\frac{1}{N_\mathcal{S}} \sum_{i=1}^{N_\mathcal{S}}[a(\mathcal{S}_i)-a(\mathcal{P})] NS​1​i=1∑NS​​[a(Si​)−a(P)]

3.1.1 Consistency and the Effect of Sample Size

The nature of the sample error depends largely on the sample size. As the sample size increases, the sample approaches the population. Attribute values will concentrate even more around the population value. The concentration around the true value indicates some kind of consistency for this particular attribute.

Consider a population P\mathcal{P}P of size N<∞N<\inftyN<∞.

  • For each nnn, we can construct the set of all possible samples

    PS(n)={S:S⊂P and ∣S∣=n}=:{S1,…SNS}\mathcal{P}_\mathcal{S}(n)=\{ \mathcal{S}: \mathcal{S}\subset \mathcal{P}\textrm{ and } |\mathcal{S}|=n \}=:\{\mathcal{S}_1,\dots \mathcal{S}_{N_\mathcal{S}}\} PS​(n)={S:S⊂P and ∣S∣=n}=:{S1​,…SNS​​}

  • For any absolute sample error c>0c>0c>0,

    Pa(c,n)={S:S∈PS(n) and ∣a(S)−a(P)∣<c}\mathcal{P}_a(c,n)=\{ \mathcal{S}: \mathcal{S}\in \mathcal{P}_\mathcal{S}(n) \textrm{ and } |a(\mathcal{S})-a(\mathcal{P})| < c\} Pa​(c,n)={S:S∈PS​(n) and ∣a(S)−a(P)∣<c}

    and define proportion

    pa(c,n)=∣Pa(c,n)∣∣PS(n)∣p_a(c,n)=\frac{|\mathcal{P}_a(c,n)|}{|\mathcal{P}_\mathcal{S}(n)|} pa​(c,n)=∣PS​(n)∣∣Pa​(c,n)∣​

    for all c>0c>0c>0 and n≤Nn\le Nn≤N.

Note that this notion of consistency is different and separate from Fisher consistency. As nnn increases, the proportion pa(c,n)→1p_a(c,n)\rightarrow 1pa​(c,n)→1 and so the bulk of the samples cluster around the population attribute.

When studying consistency, we will focus on two types of attributes:

  • Location attributes (measures of center)
    • Mean
    • Trimmed Mean: the 100% trimmed mean is the mean of the middle 100(1−2p)%100(1-2p)\%100(1−2p)% of the sorted values. Behaves similarly to mean, though less symmetric.
    • Median: quite different. When there are odd number units in the sample, the median will be one of the observed sample values.
  • Scale attributes (measure of spread)
    • Range ∣ymax−ymin∣|y_{\textrm{max}} - y_{\textrm{min}}|∣ymax​−ymin​∣, sample values are quite far from the population range, considerably underestimating its value; sample errors would be mostly negative, except ones in the rightmost bar.
    • IQR: Qy(0.75)−Qy(0.25)Q_y(0.75)-Q_y(0.25)Qy​(0.75)−Qy​(0.25), performs much better than range. However, the population IQR appears to be far more frequently underestimated than overestimated.
    • Standard Deviation: ∑u∈P(yu−yˉ)N\sqrt{ \frac{\sum_{u\in \mathcal{P}} (y_u-\bar{y})}{N}}N∑u∈P​(yu​−yˉ​)​​, behaves much more like average: sample values concentrate roughly symmetrically about the population value. As sample size increases the histogram becomes quite skewed.

Comparisons Across Attributes

Previously we defined consistency in terms of absolute sample error. This allowed us to evaluate the impact of sample size on concentration. However, if we want to compare different attributes, we use the relative absolute sample error. For any c>0c>0c>0, let Pa∗(c,n)\mathcal{P}_a^*(c,n)Pa∗​(c,n) denote the set of all samples which have relative sample error <c<c<c,

Pa∗(c,n)={S:S∈PS(n) and ∣a(S)−a(P)∣∣a(P)∣<c}\mathcal{P}_a^*(c,n)=\left\{ \mathcal{S}:\mathcal{S}\in \mathcal{P}_\mathcal{S}(n)\textrm{ and } \frac{|a(\mathcal{S}) - a(\mathcal{P})|}{ |a(\mathcal{P})|}<c\right\}Pa∗​(c,n)={S:S∈PS​(n) and ∣a(P)∣∣a(S)−a(P)∣​<c}

And define the corresponding proportion, for all c>0c>0c>0 and n≤Nn\le Nn≤N,

pa∗(c,n)=∣Pa∗(c,n)∣∣PS(n)∣\mathcal{p}_a^*(c,n)=\frac{|\mathcal{P}_a^*(c,n)|}{|\mathcal{P}_S(n)|} pa∗​(c,n)=∣PS​(n)∣∣Pa∗​(c,n)∣​

We can then plot proportion vs relative sample error with various sample size for different attributes. (see lecture notes).

3.2 Selecting Samples

Randomly selecting mmm samples. Consider drawing samples of size nnn from the population P\mathcal{P}P. The population PS\mathcal{P}_\mathcal{S}PS​ of all such samples has size M=(Nn)M={N\choose n}M=(nN​) and is denoted

PS={S1,…,SM}\mathcal{P}_\mathcal{S}=\{S_1, \dots, S_M\} PS​={S1​,…,SM​}

Any attribute a(Si)a(\mathcal{S}_i)a(Si​) is now just a variate on that unit. We then have a population of attributes

Pa(S)={a(S1),a(S2),…,a(SM)}\mathcal{P}_{a(\mathcal{S})}=\{a(\mathcal{S}_1), a(\mathcal{S}_2), \dots, a(\mathcal{S}_M) \} Pa(S)​={a(S1​),a(S2​),…,a(SM​)}

In general, it can be computationally expensive to calculate all possible samples. We don't need all possible samples. Using a subset provides a good approximation to the sampling distribution and hence the sampling error as well.

3.2.1 Quantifying Sample Error

We select a sample S\mathcal{S}S from the population PS\mathcal{P}_{\mathcal{S}}PS​ containing all available samples. We do so with some probability p(S)≥0p(\mathcal{S})\ge 0p(S)≥0 of being selected. We require of course that ∑S∈PSp(S)=1\sum_{S\in \mathcal{P}_\mathcal{S}}p(\mathcal{S})=1∑S∈PS​​p(S)=1.

We've already learnt sample error and average sample error.

We can quantify the concentration of sample errors in expectation using quantities such as

  • By sampling SSS randomly from PSP_SPS​ with probability p(S)p(S)p(S) we define the sampling bias,

    E[a(S)]−a(P)=∑s∈PSa(S)×p(S)−a(P)=∑s∈PS(a(S)−a(P))×p(S)\begin{aligned} E[a(S)]-a(P)&=\sum_{s\in P_S} a(S)\times p(S) - a(P)\\&=\sum_{s\in P_S}(a(S)-a(P))\times p(S) \end{aligned}E[a(S)]−a(P)​=s∈PS​∑​a(S)×p(S)−a(P)=s∈PS​∑​(a(S)−a(P))×p(S)​

    Sampling bias is just the expected sample error induced by the repeated random sampling of SSS from PSP_SPS​. If p(S)=1/Mp(S)=1/Mp(S)=1/M, the sampling bias is identical to the average sample error of a(P)a(P)a(P). The sampling bias depends on the attribute a(⋅)a(\cdot)a(⋅), the set of possible samples PSP_SPS​, and the sample probabilities p(S)p(S)p(S). If the sampling bias is zero then a(S)a(S)a(S) is called an unbiased estimator for a(P)a(P)a(P).
  • The sampling variance is defined as

    Var(a(S))=E[(a(S)−E(a(S))2]\textrm{Var}(a(\mathcal{S}))=E[(a(S)-E(a(S))^2] Var(a(S))=E[(a(S)−E(a(S))2]

    This quantifies dispersion in the sample errors. We may also use sampling standard deviation defined as the square root of the variance

    SD(a(S))=Var(a(S))\textrm{SD}(a(S))=\sqrt{\textrm{Var}(a(S))} SD(a(S))=Var(a(S))​

  • Given a sample S\mathcal{S}S, we would like a(S)a(S)a(S) and a(P)a(P)a(P) to be as close as possible. We can use the sampling mean squared error to quantify the expected squared distance between these two quantities.

    MSE(a(S))=E[(a(S)−a(P))2]=Var(a(S))+[sampling bias]2\begin{aligned} \textrm{MSE}(a(S)) &= E[(a(S)-a(P))^2]\\ &=\textrm{Var}(a(S)) + [\textrm{sampling bias}]^2 \end{aligned}MSE(a(S))​=E[(a(S)−a(P))2]=Var(a(S))+[sampling bias]2​

    This is a metric of "bias-variance trade off." Ideally, we would like to choose p(S)p(S)p(S) and/or PSP_SPS​, so that both the square of sampling bias and the sampling variance are as small as possible.

Attribute as an estimator: thinking of the sampling distribution of an attribute a(S)a(S)a(S) gives rise to the notion of an attribute as an estimator. We can introduce a random variable A=a~(S)A=\tilde{a}(S)A=a~(S) that takes values aaa from the distinct values of a(S)a(S)a(S) for all S∈PSS\in P_SS∈PS​. The induced probability distribution is

Pr(A=a)=∑s∈PSI(a(S)=a)×p(S)P_r(A=a)=\sum_{s\in P_S} I(a(S)=a)\times p(S) Pr​(A=a)=s∈PS​∑​I(a(S)=a)×p(S)

It follows that AAA is a discrete random variable a~(S)\tilde{a}(S)a~(S). Probability statements about its values can be made using its distribution, including its expectation, variance, etc. Each of the definitions above (sampling bias, sampling variance, sapling MSE) can be defined in terms of this random variable and the corresponding probability distribution.

3.2.3 Sampling Mechanisms

Rather than select samples at random from all possible samples, the same outcome is effected by sampling the units that will appear in any particular sample.

Rather than select S\mathcal{S}S with probability p(S)p(S)p(S) from PS={S1,…,SM}P_S=\left\{ S_1,\dots, S_M \right\}PS​={S1​,…,SM​}. We form SSS by selecting nnn units ui1,ui2,…,uinu_{i_1}, u_{i_2}, \dots, u_{i_n}ui1​​,ui2​​,…,uin​​ directly from the population of units P={u1,…,uN}P=\{u_1,\dots, u_N\}P={u1​,…,uN​}. Each unit uuu in a sample SSS is selected one at a time from the population PPP. A sequence of the first kkk units uiu_iui​ selected from P\mathcal{P}P is sk=(ui1,ui2,…,uik)s_k=(u_{i_1}, u_{i_2},\dots, u_{i_k})sk​=(ui1​​,ui2​​,…,uik​​).

A sampling mechanism is defined by the probability

  • Pr(u)\textrm{Pr}(u)Pr(u): the first unit is selected with probability Pr(u)\textrm{Pr}(u)Pr(u)
  • Pr(u∣k,sk−1)\textrm{Pr}(u|k, s_{k-1})Pr(u∣k,sk−1​): probability that unit uuu is the $k$th unit selected
  • p(sk)p(s_k)p(sk​): the probability of the sequence of the first kkk units selected is

    p(sk)=p(ui1)×p(ui2∣2,ui1)×p(ui3∣3,ui1,ui2)×⋯×p(uik∣k,ui1,ui2,…,uik−1)p(s_k)=p(u_{i_1})\times p(u_{i_2}|2, u_{i_1})\times p(u_{i_3}|3, u_{i_1}, u_{i_2})\times \dots \times p(u_{i_k}|k, u_{i_1}, u_{i_2}, \dots, u_{i_{k-1}}) p(sk​)=p(ui1​​)×p(ui2​​∣2,ui1​​)×p(ui3​​∣3,ui1​​,ui2​​)×⋯×p(uik​​∣k,ui1​​,ui2​​,…,uik−1​​)

Basic sampling mechanism:

  • Simple Random Sampling Without Replacement (SRSWOR):
    • The sampling mechanism is

      p(u)=1Np(u∣k,sk−1)=1N−k+1p(u)=\frac{1}{N}\qquad p(u|k, s_{k-1})=\frac{1}{N-k+1} p(u)=N1​p(u∣k,sk−1​)=N−k+11​

    • The probability of the sequence sns_nsn​ is

      p(sn)=1N×1N−1×⋯×1N−n+1p(s_n)=\frac{1}{N}\times \frac{1}{N-1}\times\dots\times \frac{1}{N-n+1} p(sn​)=N1​×N−11​×⋯×N−n+11​

      which is the same for all n!n!n! permutations, so p(S)=n!N(n−1)⋯(N−n+1)=n!(N−n)!N!=1(Nn)p(\textrm{S})=\frac{n!}{N(n-1)\cdots (N-n+1)}=\frac{n! (N-n)!}{N!}=\frac{1}{N\choose n}p(S)=N(n−1)⋯(N−n+1)n!​=N!n!(N−n)!​=(nN​)1​
  • Simple Random Sampling With Replacement (SRSWR)
    • The sampling mechanism is

      p(u)=1Np(u∣k,sk−1)=1Np(u)=\frac{1}{N}\qquad p(u|k, s_{k-1})=\frac{1}{N} p(u)=N1​p(u∣k,sk−1​)=N1​

      and thus a sample SSS can contain have one or replicated units
    • The probability of sequence sns_nsn​ is p(sn)=(1N)np(s_n)=\left( \frac{1}{N} \right)^np(sn​)=(N1​)n
    • Note that unlike in the case of SRSWOR, we typically treat each sns_nsn​ as an ordered sample and so p(s)=p(sn)=1Nnp(s)=p(s_n)=\frac{1}{N^n}p(s)=p(sn​)=Nn1​. The population of all samples PSP_SPS​ in this case contains M=NnM=N^nM=Nn ordered samples.
    • If we treat each sns_nsn​ as an unordered sample similar to SRSWOR we obtain p(S)=(N+n−1n)Nnp(S)=\frac{N+n-1 \choose n}{ N^n}p(S)=Nn(nN+n−1​)​
  • A Weird Hybrid Sampling Mechanism (SRSWH)
    • Suppose we perform simple random sampling with replacement except that we remove any duplicate units. The samples produced will have sizes anywhere from 1 to n according to how many distinct units were selected in a sample (sampling with replacement). Note that since the number of duplicates is a random variable, the actual sample size (n minus the number of duplicates) is also a random variable here!

3.2.4 Unit Inclusion Probabilities

The inclusion probability for unit uuu is the probability of unit uuu being included in the sample

πu=p(u∈S)=∑S∈PSp(S)I(u∈S)\pi_u=p(u\in S)=\sum_{S\in P_S}p(S)I(u\in S) πu​=p(u∈S)=S∈PS​∑​p(S)I(u∈S)

Such inclusion probabilities are of interest to calculate in addition to p(S)p(S)p(S) and they may in fact be derived from p(S)p(S)p(S). Now, consider the following random variable

Du={1u∈S0otherwiseD_u=\begin{cases} 1 & u\in S\\ 0& \textrm{otherwise} \end{cases}Du​={10​u∈Sotherwise​

DuD_uDu​ takes on the value 111 with probability equal to πu=p(u∈S)\pi_u=p(u\in S)πu​=p(u∈S) and zero otherwise.

  • The expectation of this random variable is

    E[Du]=1×p(u∈S)+0×p(Du=0)=πuE[D_u]=1\times p(u\in S) + 0\times p(D_u=0)=\pi_u E[Du​]=1×p(u∈S)+0×p(Du​=0)=πu​

  • The variance of this random variable is

    Var(Du)=E[Du2]−E[Du]2=12⋅p(Du=1)+02⋅p(Du=0)−πu2=πu−πu2=πu(1−πu)\begin{aligned} \textrm{Var}(D_u) &= E[D_u^2]-E[D_u]^2\\ &= 1^2\cdot p(D_u=1) + 0^2\cdot p(D_u = 0) -\pi_u^2\\ &= \pi_u - \pi_u^2\\ &= \pi_u (1-\pi_u) \end{aligned}Var(Du​)​=E[Du2​]−E[Du​]2=12⋅p(Du​=1)+02⋅p(Du​=0)−πu2​=πu​−πu2​=πu​(1−πu​)​

  • The probability that uuu and vvv are in the sample SSS is called the joint inclusion probability and is given by

    πuv=p(u∈S and v∈S)\pi_{uv}=p(u\in S\textrm{ and } v\in S) πuv​=p(u∈S and v∈S)

    And we have the following relationship

    Cov(Du,Dv)=E[Du⋅Dv]−E[Du]E[Dv]=E[Du⋅Dv]−πuπv=p(u∈S and v∈S)−πuπv=πuv−πuπv\begin{aligned} \textrm{Cov}(D_u, D_v)&= E[D_u\cdot D_v] - E[D_u] E[D_v]\\ &= E[D_u \cdot D_v] -\pi_u \pi_v\\ &=p(u\in S\textrm{ and } v\in S) - \pi_u \pi_v\\ &=\pi_{uv}-\pi_u\pi_v \end{aligned}Cov(Du​,Dv​)​=E[Du​⋅Dv​]−E[Du​]E[Dv​]=E[Du​⋅Dv​]−πu​πv​=p(u∈S and v∈S)−πu​πv​=πuv​−πu​πv​​

For the 2 sampling mechanisms we studied:

  • SRSWOR:
    • The inclusion probability is πu=nN\pi_u=\frac{n}{N}πu​=Nn​
    • The joint inclusion probability is πuv=n(n−1)N(N−1)\pi_{uv}=\frac{n(n-1)}{N(N-1)}πuv​=N(N−1)n(n−1)​
  • SRSWR:
    • The inclusion probability is πu=1−p(u∉S)=1−(1−1N)n\pi_u=1-p(u\notin S)=1-(1-\frac{1}{N})^nπu​=1−p(u∈/S)=1−(1−N1​)n
    • The joint inclusion probability is πuv=1−2(N−1N)n+(N−2N)n\pi_{uv}=1-2\left( \frac{N-1}{N} \right)^n+\left( \frac{N-2}{N} \right)^nπuv​=1−2(NN−1​)n+(NN−2​)n

3.2.5a Estimating Totals

Many attributes are either a total a(P)=∑u∈Pyua(P)=\sum_{u\in P}y_ua(P)=∑u∈P​yu​ of some variate yuy_uyu​ observed on every unit u∈Pu\in Pu∈P, or a function of such a total a(P)=f(∑u∈Pyu)a(P)=f\left( \sum_{u\in P}y_u \right)a(P)=f(∑u∈P​yu​).

Common totals and functions thereof:

  • Population average
  • Population variance
  • Population standard deviation
  • Number of (...), sum of indicator function
  • Proportion
  • Cumulative distribution function (CDF)
  • Quantile (the inverse of CDF) is thus an implicit function of a total

Horvitz-Thompson Estimate: a natural estimate of population total

a(P)=∑u∈Pyua(P)=\sum_{u\in P} y_u a(P)=u∈P∑​yu​

is the Horvitz-Thompson estimate is defined as

a^(P)=aHT(S)=∑u∈Syuπu\hat{a}(P)=a_{HT}(S)=\sum_{u\in S}\frac{y_u}{\pi_u} a^(P)=aHT​(S)=u∈S∑​πu​yu​​

where the contribution for each unit in the sample is weighted inversely by πu\pi_uπu​, its probability of inclusion in SSS.

  • If the probability of inclusion is small, then the weight will be high
  • If the probability of inclusion is large, then the weight will be low

Note that we use the subscript HT to distinguish the Horvitz-Thompson estimate of a(P)a(P)a(P) from other estimates based on the sample SSS.

Observe that the definition of HT estimate can be rewritten using random variable Du={1u∈S0otherwiseD_u=\begin{cases}1 & u\in S\\0&\textrm{otherwise}\end{cases}Du​={10​u∈Sotherwise​

a~HT(s)=∑u∈Syuπu=∑u∈PDu⋅yuπu\tilde{a}_{HT}(s)=\sum_{u\in S}\frac{y_u}{\pi_u}=\sum_{u\in P}D_u\cdot \frac{y_u}{\pi_u} a~HT​(s)=u∈S∑​πu​yu​​=u∈P∑​Du​⋅πu​yu​​

Note we have the following properties of DuD_uDu​, in addition to what we already know:

  • E[∑u∈PDu]=∑u∈PE[Du]=∑u∈Pπu=E[n]E[\sum_{u\in P}D_u]=\sum_{u\in P}E[D_u]=\sum_{u\in P}\pi_u=E[n]E[∑u∈P​Du​]=∑u∈P​E[Du​]=∑u∈P​πu​=E[n] (if random or nnn if fixed)
  • When sample size is fixed, ∑u∈Pπuv=u⋅πv\sum_{u\in P}\pi_{uv}=u\cdot \pi_v∑u∈P​πuv​=u⋅πv​

Properties of HT estimator:

  • The bias of HT estimator is 0!
  • The variance of HT estimator is

    Var[a~HT(S)]=∑u∈P∑v∈P(πuv−πuπv)yuπuyvπv=∑u∈P∑v∈PΔuvyuπuyvπv\textrm{Var}[\tilde{a}_{HT}(S)]=\sum_{u\in P}\sum_{v\in P} (\pi_{uv}-\pi_u\pi_v) \frac{y_u}{\pi_u}\frac{y_v}{\pi_v}=\sum_{u\in P}\sum_{v\in P} \Delta_{uv} \frac{y_u}{\pi_u}\frac{y_v}{\pi_v} Var[a~HT​(S)]=u∈P∑​v∈P∑​(πuv​−πu​πv​)πu​yu​​πv​yv​​=u∈P∑​v∈P∑​Δuv​πu​yu​​πv​yv​​

Note that because the HT estimator is unbiased, the mean squared error is simply equal to the variance.

The HT Estimate of the Variance of the HT Estimator:

Var^(a~HT(s))=∑(u,v)∈Suvquvπuv=∑u∈S∑v∈SΔuvπuvyuπuyvπv\widehat{\textrm{Var}}(\tilde{a}_{HT}(s))=\sum_{(u,v)\in S_{uv}}\frac{q_{uv}}{\pi_{uv}}=\sum_{u\in S}\sum_{v\in S} \frac{\Delta uv}{\pi_{uv}}\frac{y_u}{\pi_u}\frac{y_v}{\pi_v} Var(a~HT​(s))=(u,v)∈Suv​∑​πuv​quv​​=u∈S∑​v∈S∑​πuv​Δuv​πu​yu​​πv​yv​​

Note that the sample SuvS_{uv}Suv​ is obtained by sampling from teh population PuvP_{uv}Puv​ of all possible pairs (u,v)(u,v)(u,v). The probability that any particular pair (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) is included in teh sample is πuv>0\pi_{uv}>0πuv​>0.

Note also that the square root of this variance estimate or HT estimate of the standard deviation is commonly referred to the standard error of the estimate

SD^[a~HT(s)]=Var^(a~HT(s))\widehat{SD}[\tilde{a}_{HT}(s)]=\sqrt{\widehat{\textrm{Var}}(\tilde{a}_{HT}(s))} SD[a~HT​(s)]=Var(a~HT​(s))​

Thus, using HT estimation we are able to construct

  • an estimate of the population total
  • an estimate of the variance of this estimator
  • both estimators are unbiased.

Confidence interval (referring to 3.2.5b):

  • Recognize that the sampling distribution appears bell-shaped and symmetric
  • We could approximate the distrubtion by a normal distribution
  • the interval tha contains 95% of the distrubtion's value is

    u±z1−.05/2×σ≈μ±2σu\pm z_{1-.05/2}\times \sigma\approx \mu\pm 2\sigma u±z1−.05/2​×σ≈μ±2σ

3.2.6 Sampling

The pair (PS,p(S))(P_{S}, p(S))(PS​,p(S)) is called a sampling design. SRSWOR, SRSWR, SRSWH frameworks provide examples of different sampling designs. We may choose PSP_SPS​ so that values a(S)a(S)a(S) for S∈PSS\in P_SS∈PS​ are constrained to be near a(P)a(P)a(P). We may choose p(S)p(S)p(S) so that samples S∈PSS\in P_SS∈PS​ that have a(S)a(S)a(S) close to a(P)a(P)a(P) have higher probability p(S)p(S)p(S) of being selected.

Within the Horvitz-Thompson framework we know that

MSE[a~HT(S)]=Var[a~HT(S)]=−12∑u∈P∑v∈PΔuv(yuπu−yvπv)2\textrm{MSE}[\tilde{a}_{HT}(S)]=\textrm{Var}[\tilde{a}_{HT}(S)]=-\frac{1}{2}\sum_{u\in P}\sum_{v\in P}\Delta_{uv}\left( \frac{y_u}{\pi_u}-\frac{y_v}{\pi_v} \right)^2 MSE[a~HT​(S)]=Var[a~HT​(S)]=−21​u∈P∑​v∈P∑​Δuv​(πu​yu​​−πv​yv​​)2

This gave us insight into how we might best choose a sampling design. E.g. choose πu∝yu\pi_u\propto y_uπu​∝yu​ then the variance (and MSE) will be zero!

Much of survey sampling is concerned with how best to choose the sampling design (PS,p(S))(P_S, p(S))(PS​,p(S)) to reduce the MSE of an estimator (attribute) of interest.

The goal is to construct a sampling design to reduce the variability.

Stratified Sampling: the population is split into HHH non-overlapping groups called strata, and we sample without replacement from each stratum

  • Each stratum has NhN_hNh​ units, N1+⋯+NH=NN_1+\cdots +N_H=NN1​+⋯+NH​=N
  • We sample nhn_hnh​ from each stratum, n1+⋯+nH=nn_1+\cdots + n_H=nn1​+⋯+nH​=n

One can split the population into 2 groups using the median.

Notation: n=(3,3)n=(3,3)n=(3,3) means stratified sampling (2 groups), each group is sampled 3 times.

This technique is extremely powerful in getting an accurate estimation with minimal sampling.

4 Inductive Inference

Assumption: a probabilitistic sampling mechanism is used.

4.1 Sources of Error

The path of inductive inference is shown below:

  • We want to estimate attributes of Target Population, but can only use a similar Study Population
  • Sample from Study Population
  • Measured values from the sample
  • Make induction from measured values to estimate target population.

4.1.1 Target and Study Populations

The target population is the population about which we would like to draw an inference, but the study population is the population from which samples are taken.

Study Error a(Pstudy)−a(Ptarget)a(P_{\textrm{study}})-a(P_{\textrm{target}})a(Pstudy​)−a(Ptarget​) is the difference between the attribute evaluated on the two populations.

Then if we obtain a sample SSS to draw inferences about the target population PtargetP_{\textrm{target}}Ptarget​ the error for a given attribute a(⋅)a(\cdot)a(⋅) is

a(S)−a(Ptarget)=[a(S)−a(Pstudy)]+[a(Pstudy)−a(Ptarget)]=sample error+study error\begin{aligned} a(S)-a(P_{\textrm{target}})&=[a(S)-a(P_{\textrm{study}})]+[a(P_{\textrm{study}})-a(P_{\textrm{target}})]\\ &=\textrm{sample error} + \textrm{study error} \end{aligned}a(S)−a(Ptarget​)​=[a(S)−a(Pstudy​)]+[a(Pstudy​)−a(Ptarget​)]=sample error+study error​

We use probabilistic sampling to control the sample error but not the study error. Making the case that the study error is small remains a challenge, and sometimes, it is not even within the domain of statistics.

Every measurement system has at least 3 sources of potential error:

  1. the measuring device (sometimes called the gauge)
  2. the person reading on recording the measurement (some called the operator)
  3. the method followed to take the measurement

4.2.0 Comparing Sub-populations

Suppose we have population P={P1,P2}P=\{ P_1, P_2\}P={P1​,P2​} and interest lies in comparing some attributes across 2 sub-populations: a(P1)a(P_1)a(P1​) vs a(P2)a(P_2)a(P2​).

  • We could compare the two sub-population attributes by way of a difference: a(P1)−a(P2)a(P_1)-a(P_2)a(P1​)−a(P2​).
  • We could compare the two sub-population attributes by way of a ratio a(P1)/a(P2)a(P_1)/a(P_2)a(P1​)/a(P2​).

Note: that when the attribute is a measure of location, sub-population comparisons are typically based on differences and when the attribute is a measure of spread, comparisons are typically based on ratios.

4.2.1 Anatomy of a Significance Test

We would like to quantify numerically how unusually the difference between a(P1)a(P_1)a(P1​) and a(P2)a(P_2)a(P2​) is relative to randomly mixed sub-populations.

This leads to the significance test:

  1. Null hypothesis H0H_0H0​: sub-populations were randomly drawn from the same population.
    • There's also the alternative hypothesis HAH_AHA​ that is the complement of H0H_0H0​.
  2. Discrepancy measure D(P1,P2)D(P_1, P_2)D(P1​,P2​): measures how inconsistent our data is with the null hypothesis where large values indicate evidence against the null hypothesis. In other statistical texts the discrepancy measure is often referred to as a test statistic.
    • If we want to compare measures of location, the discrepancy measure is typically based on differences, e.g. for average

    D(P1,P2)=∣yˉ1−yˉ2∣D(P_1, P_2)=|\bar{y}_1 -\bar{y}_2| D(P1​,P2​)=∣yˉ​1​−yˉ​2​∣

    • If we want to compare measures of spread the discrepancy measure is typically based on ratios. e.g. for standard deviationF

    D(P1,P2)=∣SD(P1)SD(P2)−1∣D(P_1, P_2)=\left| \frac{SD(P_1)}{SD(P_2)} - 1 \right| D(P1​,P2​)=∣∣​SD(P2​)SD(P1​)​−1∣∣​

  3. Observed discrepancy: calculating the discrepancy measure on the two observed (unshuffled) sub-populations.
  4. Observed p-value: the probability that a randomly shuffled sub-population has a discrepancy measure at least as large as the observed discrepancy; where small values indicate evidence against the null hypothesis. In other words, the observed p-value is the probability of observing a result at least as extreme as what we observed, if the H0H_0H0​ is true. where dobs=D(P1,P2)d_{\textrm{obs}}=D(P_1,P_2)dobs​=D(P1​,P2​).

p value=P(D≥dobs:H0 is true)≈1M∑i=1MI(D(P1∗,P2∗)≥dobs)\begin{aligned}p\textrm{ value}&=P(D\ge d_{\textrm{obs}}:H_0\textrm{ is true})\\ &\approx \frac{1}{M}\sum_{i=1}^M I(D(P_1^*, P_2^*)\ge d_{\textrm{obs}}) \end{aligned}p value​=P(D≥dobs​:H0​ is true)≈M1​i=1∑M​I(D(P1∗​,P2∗​)≥dobs​)​

If the p-vlue is very small then either the null hypothesis is true and we have observed a very unusual value of dobsd_{\textrm{obs}}dobs​ OR the null hypothesis is false.

  • p value<0.001p\textrm{ value}<0.001p value<0.001 means that there is very strong evidence against H0H_0H0​
  • 0.001<p value<0.010.001<p\textrm{ value}<0.010.001<p value<0.01 means that there is strong evidence against H0H_0H0​
  • 0.01<p value<0.050.01<p\textrm{ value}<0.050.01<p value<0.05 means there is evidence against H0H_0H0​
  • 0.05<p value<0.10.05<p\textrm{ value}<0.10.05<p value<0.1 means that there is weak evidence against H0H_0H0​
  • p value>0.1p\textrm{ value}>0.1p value>0.1 means that there is no evidence against H0H_0H0​

Significance Testing Errors: there is Type 1 error (false positive) and Type 2 error (false negative).

4.2.2 A t-like Discrepancy Measure

When comparing two sub-populations on the basis of a measure of location, one particular useful discrepancy measure is

D(P1,P2)=a(P1)−a(P2)SD[a(P1)−a(P2)]D(P_1, P_2)=\frac{a(P_1)- a(P_2)}{SD[a(P_1)-a(P_2)]} D(P1​,P2​)=SD[a(P1​)−a(P2​)]a(P1​)−a(P2​)​

This discrepancy measure is physically dimensionless. This naturally makes the discrepancy measure scale-invariant.

The challenge is determining the denominator of the discrepancy measure. In rare cases, the denominator might be known and then this discrepancy measure is a rescaling of a(P1)−a(P2)a(P_1)-a(P_2)a(P1​)−a(P2​) and would not yield different results.

Suppose that the population P1,P2P_1, P_2P1​,P2​ are random and independently drawn from the same larger population. Then the denominator should be instead

SD(a~(P1)−a~(P2))=Var(a~(P1))+Var(a~(P2))SD(\tilde{a}(P_1) - \tilde{a}(P_2))=\sqrt{\textrm{Var}(\tilde{a}(P_1)) + \textrm{Var}(\tilde{a}(P_2))} SD(a~(P1​)−a~(P2​))=Var(a~(P1​))+Var(a~(P2​))​

But determining the form of SD[a~(P1)−a~(P2)]SD[\tilde{a}(P_1) - \tilde{a}(P_2)]SD[a~(P1​)−a~(P2​)] can also be difficult. Except in the common special case when a(P)a(P)a(P) is an average.

Differences in Averages: suppose we were interested in differences in averages: In this case a(Pi)=Y‾ia(P_i)=\overline{Y}_ia(Pi​)=Yi​ and PiP_iPi​ has size Ni,i=1,2N_i, i=1,2Ni​,i=1,2. And the discrepancy measure becomes

D(P1,P2)=Y‾1−Y‾2σ~2N1+σ~2N2D(P_1, P_2)=\frac{\overline{Y}_1-\overline{Y}_2}{\sqrt{\frac{\tilde{\sigma}^2}{N_1}+\frac{\tilde{\sigma}^2}{N_2}}} D(P1​,P2​)=N1​σ~2​+N2​σ~2​​Y1​−Y2​​

where σ~\tilde{\sigma}σ~ is an estimator of the standard deviation of the YYY values in the population P={P1,P2}P=\left\{ P_1, P_2 \right\}P={P1​,P2​},

  • If σ~1\tilde{\sigma}_1σ~1​ and σ~2\tilde{\sigma}_2σ~2​ denote the estimators of the standard deviations from each of P1P_1P1​ and P2P_2P2​ respectively, then the pooled estimator of σ\sigmaσ would be

    σ~=(N1−1)σ~12+(N2−1)σ~22(N1−1)+(N2−1)\tilde{\sigma}=\sqrt{\frac{(N_1-1)\tilde{\sigma}_1^2 + (N_2-1)\tilde{\sigma}_2^2}{(N_1-1)+(N_2-1)}} σ~=(N1​−1)+(N2​−1)(N1​−1)σ~12​+(N2​−1)σ~22​​​

  • Note: if it were inappropriate to assume the variability in the two sub-populations was equivalent we could instead use the denominator

    σ~12N1+σ~22N2\sqrt{\frac{\tilde{\sigma}_1^2}{N_1}+\frac{\tilde{\sigma}_2^2}{N_2}} N1​σ~12​​+N2​σ~22​​​

This just looks like the t-test. This is the two-sample student t statistics used to test the equality of the means of two normal distributions with common but unknown standard deviation σ\sigmaσ. If the YYY values were in fact normally distributed, the discrepancy measure would follow a Student t distribution with N1+N2−2N_1 + N_2 - 2N1​+N2​−2 degrees of freedom under the null hypothesis that the means were identical.

Note, however, in our procedure of randomly mixing the populations we make no such normality assumption. We simply proceed with this discrepancy measure just as we did with the earlier measures. The only difference is that now we need to first calculate the denominator (the standard error).

4.2.3 Multiple Testing

In general, to compare sub-populations we could use any number of discrepancy measures D1,D2,…,DkD_1, D_2, \dots, D_kD1​,D2​,…,Dk​ each with an associated ppp-value p1,…,pkp_1, \dots, p_kp1​,…,pk​. However, when a family of statistical inferences is considered simultaneously one encounters

  • the more inferences made, the more likely an error is going to occur
  • e.g. Even if H0H_0H0​ is true, the more discrepancy measures (and hence tests) we consider, the more likely it becomes that one of them will erroneously suggest that null hypothesis should be rejected.

If a single test has probability α\alphaα of yielding a Type I error, then this probability becomes inflated when considering KKK simultaneous tests. Such an inflation is commonly quantified by two metrics:

  • The family-wise error rate (FWER) is the probability of making a Type I Error on any of the K tests.

    p(at least 1 T1 Err)=1−p(No T1 Err)=1−∏i=1kp(No T1 on test K)=1−∏i=1k(1−α)=1−(1−α)k\begin{aligned} p(\textrm{at least 1 T1 Err})&=1-p(\textrm{No T1 Err})\\ &=1-\prod_{i=1}^k p(\textrm{No T1 on test K})\\ &=1-\prod_{i=1}^k (1-\alpha)\\ &=1-(1-\alpha)^k \end{aligned}p(at least 1 T1 Err)​=1−p(No T1 Err)=1−i=1∏k​p(No T1 on test K)=1−i=1∏k​(1−α)=1−(1−α)k​

  • The false discovery rate (FDR) is the expected number of Type I Error in KKK tests.

Combining Information Across Tests: to consider the p-values collectively we might consider the smallest of them as measuring the combined evidence against the null hypothesis, i.e. p valuemin⁡=min⁡k=1,…Kpkp\textrm{ value}_{\min}=\min_{k=1,\dots K}p_kp valuemin​=mink=1,…K​pk​

  • Note that this is appropriate only because the ppp-values are on a common (interpretable) scale, i.e. they're probabilities
  • We could not, for instance, combine discrepancy measures in the same way. These are on different scales.

The smaller the value of p valuemin⁡p\textrm{ value}_{\min}p valuemin​ the greater is the evidence against the null hypothesis.

We can construct a discrepancy measure out of it:

D∗=1−p valuemin⁡D^*=1-p\textrm{ value}_{\min} D∗=1−p valuemin​

D∗D^*D∗ is defined so that large values, again, indicate evidence against the null hypothesis. Therefore, D∗D^*D∗ is a discrepancy measure.

If the observed value of D∗D^*D∗ is dobs∗d_{\textrm{obs}}^*dobs∗​, then the p-value that describes this combined evidence is denoted by

p value∗=P(D∗≥dobs∗∣H0 is true)p\textrm{ value}^*=P(D^* \ge d_{\textrm{obs}}^*|H_0\textrm{ is true}) p value∗=P(D∗≥dobs∗​∣H0​ is true)

p value∗p\textrm{ value}^*p value∗ will necessarily be larger than p valuemin⁡p\textrm{ value}_{\min}p valuemin​ because p valuemin⁡p\textrm{ value}_{\min}p valuemin​ is the smallest significance level. Given the data, all probabilities are proportions, hence D∗D^*D∗ and p value∗p\textrm{ value}^*p value∗ can be calculated.

Refer to lecture notes on how to estimate dobs∗d_{\textrm{obs}}^*dobs∗​ and ppp value.
