4.3.1 Revisiting Sampling Distribution

Recall that when we look at a(S)a(S)a(S) for all possible samples SSS of some size nnn from a population PPP that the values of a(S)a(S)a(S) have a distribution. We call this the sampling distribution of a~(S)\tilde{a}(S)a~(S)

Quantifying the spread using the distribution and quantiles is useful but requires having observed all possible samples.

  1. Alternatively, we could instead consider a large number of possible samples to approximate the sampling distribution.
  2. Or we could approximate the sampling distribution via a normal distribution to simplify calculations.
  3. Or, we could approximate the sampling distribution via resampling method such as the bootstrap (4.4 and 4.5)

For average, normal approximation is pretty good, except for in the tails. The normal approximation provides a model for the sampling distribution and can be used as a basis to construct confidence intervals for population averages.

4.3.2 Random vs Observed Intervals

Recall the estimator a~(P)=μ~=Y‾\tilde{a}(P)=\tilde{\mu}=\overline{Y}a~(P)=μ~​=Y (a random variable) has the following properties: E[Y‾]=μE[\overline{Y}]=\muE[Y]=μ and Var(Y‾)=σ2/n\textrm{Var}(\overline{Y})=\sigma^2/nVar(Y)=σ2/n where σ2=1N∑u∈P(yu−μ)2\sigma^2=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{u\in P}(y_u-\mu)^2σ2=N1​∑u∈P​(yu​−μ)2 is the population variance.

If the normality assumption holds (this may be appropriate due to the CLT) then the estimator a~(P)=Y‾\tilde{a}(P)=\overline{Y}a~(P)=Y hs the following distribution: Y‾∼N(μ,σ2/n)\overline{Y}\sim N(\mu, \sigma^2/n)Y∼N(μ,σ2/n). Standardizing this random variable yields

Z=Y‾−μσ/n∼N(0,1)Z=\frac{\overline{Y}-\mu}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}}\sim N(0,1) Z=σ/n​Y−μ​∼N(0,1)

Strictly speaking we are dealing with a finite population and so our variance term should include a finite population correction:

Var(Y‾)=σ2n(N−nN−1)\textrm{Var}(\overline{Y})=\frac{\sigma^2}{n}\left( \frac{N-n}{N-1} \right) Var(Y)=nσ2​(N−1N−n​)

So for completeness,

Y‾∼N(μ,σ2n(N−nN−1))Z=Y‾−μσnN−nN−1∼N(0,1)\overline{Y}\sim N\left( \mu, \frac{\sigma^2}{n}\left( \frac{N-n}{N-1} \right) \right)\qquad Z=\frac{\overline{Y}-\mu}{\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}\sqrt{\frac{N-n}{N-1}}}\sim N(0,1) Y∼N(μ,nσ2​(N−1N−n​))Z=n​σ​N−1N−n​​Y−μ​∼N(0,1)

Random intervals: using the standardized random variable and specified p∈(0,1)p\in (0,1)p∈(0,1) we can find a constant c>0c>0c>0 such that

1−p=P(−c≤Z≤c)1-p = P(-c\le Z \le c) 1−p=P(−c≤Z≤c)

Rearranging this statement yields a random interval which contains μ\muμ with probability 1−p1-p1−p.

[Y‾−cσnN−nN−1,Y‾+cσnN−nN−1)\left[\overline{Y}-c \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}\sqrt{\frac{N-n}{N-1}}, \overline{Y} +c \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}\sqrt{\frac{N-n}{N-1}} \right)[Y−cn​σ​N−1N−n​​,Y+cn​σ​N−1N−n​​)

This interval is considered random because it's never actually observed and is defined in terms of random variables.

  • 1−p1-p1−p is therefore called the coverage probability.
  • μ\muμ is contained in or covered by such an interval 100(1−p)%100(1-p)\%100(1−p)% of the time
  • All these intervals have the same width, they just different (random) centres.

The normal distribution is symmetric about its mean μ\muμ, so p,cp,cp,c are related through 1−p=Pr(−c<Z≤c)1-p=\textrm{Pr}(-c<Z\le c)1−p=Pr(−c<Z≤c), or equivalently 1−p/2=Pr(Z≤c)1-p/2=\textrm{Pr}(Z\le c)1−p/2=Pr(Z≤c)

Observed Intervals: in practice, we will have only one sample, and thus a single numerical average yˉ\bar{y}yˉ​. And thus a single instance of these randomly generated intervals (probability of containing μ\muμ). In particular, we observe:

[y‾−cσnN−nN−1,y‾+cσnN−nN−1]\left[\overline{y}-c \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}\sqrt{\frac{N-n}{N-1}}, \overline{y} +c \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}\sqrt{\frac{N-n}{N-1}} \right][y​−cn​σ​N−1N−n​​,y​+cn​σ​N−1N−n​​]

Such observed intervals are referred to as confidence intervals and you must take care to distinguish them conceptually from a random interval. In the context of random intervals, probabilistic statements are sensible. However, an observed confidence interval is not random, it either contains μ\muμ or it doesn't. Probability statements are inreference to the method used to generate the intervals, not to the particular interval we have observed.

If the normality assumption holds up, 100(1−p)%100(1-p)\%100(1−p)% of such intervals will contain μ\muμ. We thus have some confidence that our particular observed interval will contain μ\muμ as well, but unfortunately we will never know if it does. The larger 1−p1-p1−p, the more confident we are that the interval will contain μ\muμ.

4.3.3 Student t Based Intervals

Fir any saple attributes a(S)a(S)a(S) (e.g. Horvitz-Thompson estimators), we can estimate the standar deviation SD[a~(S)]SD[\tilde{a}(S)]SD[a~(S)] of the sampling distribution of a~(S)\tilde{a}(S)a~(S)

The standard error is an estimate of the standard deviation of the corresponding estimator (based on a single sample SSS):

SE[a(S)]=SD^[a~(S)]SE[a(S)]=\widehat{SD}[\tilde{a}(S)] SE[a(S)]=SD[a~(S)]

Note that the standard error is based on one sample, it has corresponding estimator with a sampling distribution denoted by

SE~[a(S)]orSD~[a~(S)]\widetilde{SE}[a(S)]\quad \textrm{or}\quad \widetilde{SD}[\tilde{a}(S)] SE[a(S)]orSD[a~(S)]

based on all possible samples.

We can then calculate

Z=a(S)−a(P)SE(a(S))=a(S)−a(P)SD^(a~(S))Z=\frac{a(S)-a(P)}{SE(a(S))}=\frac{a(S)-a(P)}{\widehat{SD}(\tilde{a}(S))} Z=SE(a(S))a(S)−a(P)​=SD(a~(S))a(S)−a(P)​

Note that using the estimate SE in place of SD will increase the variability of the random intervals. The corresponding estimator has much more variability - since we have to estimate SD^\widehat{SD}SD now as well.

The normal distribution is not a good approximation when we estimate the standard deviation, as such, under the normality assumption we use the t distribution

Y‾−μσ~/n∼tn−1\frac{\overline{Y}-\mu}{\tilde{\sigma}/\sqrt{n}} \sim t_{n-1} σ~/n​Y−μ​∼tn−1​

where tn−1t_{n-1}tn−1​ is a known distribution. This statistic is called a pivotal quantity because it is a function of the sample data (Yu,u∈S)(Y_u, u\in S)(Yu​,u∈S) and unknown parameter (μ)(\mu)(μ) and its sampling distribution is completely known. Now if we suppose the pivot

a~(S)−a(P)SD~(a~(S))∼tn−1\frac{\tilde{a}(S)-a(P)}{\widetilde{SD}(\tilde{a}(S))} \sim t_{n-1} SD(a~(S))a~(S)−a(P)​∼tn−1​

Then we choose a p∈(0,1)p\in (0,1)p∈(0,1) and a corresponding c>0c>0c>0

1−p=Pr(−c≤a~(S)−a(P)SD~(a~(S))≤c)=Pr(a~(S)−c×SD~[a~(S)]≤μ≤a~(S)+c×SD~[a~(S)])\begin{aligned} 1-p &= Pr\left( -c\le \frac{\tilde{a}(S)-a(P)}{\widetilde{SD}(\tilde{a}(S))} \le c \right)\\ &=Pr(\tilde{a}(S)-c\times \widetilde{SD}[\tilde{a}(S)]\le \mu\le \tilde{a}(S)+c\times \widetilde{SD}[\tilde{a}(S)]) \end{aligned}1−p​=Pr(−c≤SD(a~(S))a~(S)−a(P)​≤c)=Pr(a~(S)−c×SD[a~(S)]≤μ≤a~(S)+c×SD[a~(S)])​

This random interval has both a random center and a random length. The value of ccc is deterined using the ttt distribution with n−1n-1n−1 degrees of freedom. (nnn is sample size)

In the special case that a(P)=Y‾a(P)=\overline{Y}a(P)=Y is the population average, then

  • The standard deviation is (known or unknown)

    SD[a~(S)]=σn×N−nN−1SD[\tilde{a}(S)]=\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}\times\sqrt{\frac{N-n}{N-1}} SD[a~(S)]=n​σ​×N−1N−n​​

  • The standard deviation estimator is (random variable, based on all possible sample)

    SD~[a~(S)]=σ~n×N−nN−1\widetilde{SD}[\tilde{a}(S)]=\frac{\tilde{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}}\times\sqrt{\frac{N-n}{N-1}} SD[a~(S)]=n​σ~​×N−1N−n​​

  • The standard deviation estimate (the standard error) is (based on a single sample SSS)

    SD^[a~(S)]=σ^n×N−nN−1\widehat{SD}[\tilde{a}(S)]=\frac{\hat{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}}\times\sqrt{\frac{N-n}{N-1}} SD[a~(S)]=n​σ^​×N−1N−n​​

Thus the random interval in this case is

[Y‾−c×σ~nN−nN−1,Y‾+c×σ~nN−nN−1]\left[ \overline{Y}-c\times \frac{\tilde{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}} \sqrt{\frac{N-n}{N-1}}, \overline{Y} + c\times\frac{\tilde{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}} \sqrt{\frac{N-n}{N-1}} \right] [Y−c×n​σ~​N−1N−n​​,Y+c×n​σ~​N−1N−n​​]

The corresponding confidence interval (based on a single sample) is

[yˉ−c×σ^nN−nN−1,yˉ+c×σ^nN−nN−1]\left[ \bar{y}-c\times \frac{\hat{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}} \sqrt{\frac{N-n}{N-1}}, \bar{y} + c\times\frac{\hat{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}} \sqrt{\frac{N-n}{N-1}} \right] [yˉ​−c×n​σ^​N−1N−n​​,yˉ​+c×n​σ^​N−1N−n​​]

Note: in the formula above σ\sigmaσ denotes the population standard deviation, which may be estimated in a sample by

σ^=∑u∈S(yu−yˉ)2n\hat{\sigma}=\sqrt{\frac{\sum_{u\in S}(y_u - \bar{y})^2}{n}} σ^=n∑u∈S​(yu​−yˉ​)2​​

Also note: we can find the exact coverage probability by calculating all possible confidence intervals, and thn find the ratio of intervals that cover the value μ\muμ.

4.3.4 Connection to Hypothesis Testing

Note that there is a one-to-one correspondence between confidence intervals and hypothesis tests. Thus, if one wished to test a hypothesis (like H0:a(P)=aH_0:a(P)=aH0​:a(P)=a) about a population attribute, they could do so with an appropriately defined confidence interval.

  • Suppose that there exists a threshold below which a p-value would be sufficiently small so as to disbelieve the null hypothesis. This is often referred to as the significance level of the test.
  • If the same pivotal quantity is used as both a discrepancy measure for the test and the basis for a confidence interval, the 100(1−p)%100(1-p)\%100(1−p)% confidence interval for a(P)a(P)a(P) contains all values of aaa which the test of H0:a(P)=aH_0:a(P)=aH0​:a(P)=a would yield a ppp-value >p>p>p.
  • Stated more usefully: do not reject H0:a(P)=aH_0:a(P)=aH0​:a(P)=a at a 100p%100p\%100p% significance level if and only if aaa is contained in the 100(1−p)%100(1-p)\%100(1−p)% confidence interval for a(P)a(P)a(P).

4.4 Resampling

Sometimes, the population from which our sample was taken cannot generally be repeatedly sampled and we only have one sample. Resampling method aim to mimic the process by repeatedly sampling SSS as if it were PPP. In particular, we draw BBB samples S1∗,…,SB∗S_1^*, \dots, S_B^*S1∗​,…,SB∗​ of size nnn independently from a population P∗P^*P∗. Ideally, P∗P^*P∗ would be the study population PPP, but as already mentioned this would require repeated sampling from the population. Instead we use a sample SSS as estimate of the population PPP, i.e. P^=S\hat{P}=SP^=S. Note, however, that in principle we could use any estimate of the study population.

The sample population has only nnn units, so the without-replacement sampling mechanism will immediately exhaust the population. Therefore we sample with replacement. Thus an approximate sampling distribution is obtained by drawing BBB samples S1∗,…,SB∗S_1^*, \dots, S_B^*S1∗​,…,SB∗​ of size nnn from P∗P^*P∗ with replacement, and on each bootstrap sample calculate the attribute value a(S1∗),…,a(SB∗)a(S_1^*),\dots, a(S_B^*)a(S1∗​),…,a(SB∗​).

4.4.1 The Bootstrap Method

The distribution of any attribute over the bootstrap samples Si∗S_i^*Si∗​ from P∗P^*P∗ is a bootstrap estimate of the same attribute over all possible samples SiS_iSi​ from PPP.

The bootstrap estimate is at best as good as a(S)a(S)a(S). However, the bootstrap distribution gives a sense of how an attribute varies. Therefore, to get an idea of the variability in a sampling distribution we can take the standard deviation of the bootstrap distribution.

To easily compare the variability we can construct histograms for each of the following errors:

  • Sample error = a(S)−a(P)a(S)-a(P)a(S)−a(P)
  • Bootstrap sample error = a(S∗)−a(S)a(S^*)-a(S)a(S∗)−a(S)

In general, for any attribute a(P)a(P)a(P), the standard deviation of the corresponding sample attribute's estimator can be estimated from the bootstrap distribution with

SD^∗[a~(S∗)]=∑b=1B(a(Sb∗)−aˉ∗)2B\widehat{SD}_*[\tilde{a}(S^*)]=\sqrt{\frac{\sum_{b=1}^B (a(S_b^*)-\bar{a}^*)^2}{B}} SD∗​[a~(S∗)]=B∑b=1B​(a(Sb∗​)−aˉ∗)2​​

where aˉ∗\bar{a}^*aˉ∗ is the average over the bootstrap sample s1∗,…,sB∗s_1^*, \dots, s_B^*s1∗​,…,sB∗​. Since BBB is usually large, it does not make any practical difference whether we use BBB or B−1B-1B−1 in the denominator of the standard deviation. This is an estimate of the standard deviation of the sampling distribution for the attribute a(S)a(S)a(S) which is called the standard error.

Note: if the sample is not a good representation of the population, the standard deviation estimate might be quite different from the actual standard deviation.

A comment on nnn vs n−1n-1n−1. For the bootstrap interval calculations, a divisor of nnn is preferred since we are treating the sample as a population. This version has the advantage of being replication invariant. Replication invariant estimates are preferred and are often called plug in estimates in the bootstrap literature.

Estimating and correcting for sampling bias. Recall that the sampling bias of an attribute is defined as, sampling bias =E[a~(S)]−a(P)= E[\tilde{a}(S)]-a(P)=E[a~(S)]−a(P). We can use the bootstrap to estimate sampling bias via sampling bias^=\widehat{\textrm{sampling bias}}=sampling bias​= average bootstrap sample error =aˉ∗−a(S)= \bar{a}^*-a(S)=aˉ∗−a(S), where aˉ∗=1B∑b=1Ba(Sb∗)\bar{a}^*=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{b=1}^B a(S_b^*)aˉ∗=B1​∑b=1B​a(Sb∗​).

When an estimator is biased we would like to correct it, i.e. make it unbiased. If in theory, a(S)a(S)a(S) was biased and we knew the bias then we could subtract the correction from our attribute to make a new attribute a∗(S)a^*(S)a∗(S) that is unbiased. To verify that a∗(S)a^*(S)a∗(S) is unbiased: E[a∗(S)]=E[a(S)−sampling bias]=E[a(S)−E[a(S)]+a(P)]=a(P)E[a^*(S)]=E[a(S)-\textrm{sampling bias}]=E[a(S)-E[a(S)] +a(P)]=a(P)E[a∗(S)]=E[a(S)−sampling bias]=E[a(S)−E[a(S)]+a(P)]=a(P). However, we don't typically know the sampling bias, so instead we could use the bootstrap estimate of it. The bias-corrected bootstrap estimate is

a(S)−sampling bias^(a~(S))=a(S)−[aˉ∗−a(S)]=2a(S)−aˉ∗\begin{aligned} a(S)-\widehat{\textrm{sampling bias}}(\tilde{a}(S)) &= a(S) - [\bar{a}^*-a(S)]\\ &= 2 a(S) - \bar{a}^* \end{aligned}a(S)−sampling bias​(a~(S))​=a(S)−[aˉ∗−a(S)]=2a(S)−aˉ∗​

4.4.2 Bootstrap Confidence Intervals

Recall that confidence interval for sample averages tend to have the following structure [yˉ−cSD^(yˉ),yˉ+cSD^(yˉ)][\bar{y}-c \widehat{SD}(\bar{y}), \bar{y}+c\widehat{SD}(\bar{y})][yˉ​−cSD(yˉ​),yˉ​+cSD(yˉ​)]. Under an assumption of normality we might pick ccc such that P(Z≤c)=1−p/2P(Z\le c)=1-p/2P(Z≤c)=1−p/2 generates a 100(1−p)%100(1-p)\%100(1−p)% confidence interval.

If the bootstrap distribution is approximately normal, rather than estimating SD^(Y‾)\widehat{SD}(\overline{Y})SD(Y) by σ^nN−nN−1\frac{\hat{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}} \sqrt{\frac{N-n}{N-1}}n​σ^​N−1N−n​​. We might estimate SD^(Y‾)\widehat{SD}(\overline{Y})SD(Y) using the standard deviation of the bootstrap distribution of Y‾\overline{Y}Y. The attraction of this approach, if it works, is that the same approach could be used for any attribute a(S)a(S)a(S).

A 95%95\%95% normal bootstrap interval for a population attribute a(P)a(P)a(P) is a(S)±1.96×SD^∗(a(S))a(S)\pm 1.96\times \widehat{SD}_*(a(S))a(S)±1.96×SD∗​(a(S)).

What does the 95%95\%95% mean? We expect 95%95\%95% of the bootstrap CIs to cover a(P)a(P)a(P) under repeated sampling.

Estimating coverage probability for the bootstrap confidence interval: We generate 100 samples of size nnn, and for each sample

  1. Generate BBB bootstrap samples to obtain the bootstrap estimate of the standard deviation, SD^(Y‾)\widehat{SD}(\overline{Y})SD(Y).
  2. Construct 95%95\%95% confidence interval using c=1.96c=1.96c=1.96
  3. The percentation of bootstrap intervals that actually cover the population attribute is the coverage probability.

Under-coverage is perhaps not unexpected as the ccc value is based on a normal distribution which may not apply.

4.4.2b Bootstrap-t Confidence Intervals

When a(S)=yˉa(S)=\bar{y}a(S)=yˉ​, we have seen that quantity z=a~(S)−a(P)SD~(a~(S))z=\frac{\tilde{a}(S)-a(P)}{\widetilde{SD}(\tilde{a}(S))}z=SD(a~(S))a~(S)−a(P)​ is approximately pivotal and its sampling distribution (over all possible samples) is well approximated by a ttt-density. We can confirm this approximation using simulation:

  1. Generating S1,…,SMS_1,\dots, S_MS1​,…,SM​.
  2. For each sample calculate Zi=a(Si)−a(P)SE^[a(Si)]=a(Si)−a(P)SD^[a~(Si)]Z_i=\frac{a(S_i)-a(P)}{\widehat{SE}[a(S_i)]}=\frac{a(S_i)-a(P)}{\widehat{SD}[\tilde{a}(S_i)]}Zi​=SE[a(Si​)]a(Si​)−a(P)​=SD[a~(Si​)]a(Si​)−a(P)​ based on sample SiS_iSi​
  3. An estimate of tn−1t_{n-1}tn−1​ can be constructed with {Z1,…,ZM}\left\{ Z_1, \dots, Z_M \right\}{Z1​,…,ZM​} which is an estimate of the sampling distribution
  4. This means we require an estimate of the standard deviation of the estimator of a standard error, e.g. when a(S)a(S)a(S) is the average, one estimate is SE^(a(Si))=SD^[a~(Si)]=σ^n×N−nN−1\widehat{SE}(a(S_i))=\widehat{SD}[\tilde{a}(S_i)]=\frac{\hat{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}}\times \sqrt{\frac{N-n}{N-1}}SE(a(Si​))=SD[a~(Si​)]=n​σ^​×N−1N−n​​ where σ^\hat{\sigma}σ^ is the sample standard deviation. Indeed, to calculate ZiZ_iZi​, we need a(Si)a(S_i)a(Si​) and SD^[a~(Si)]\widehat{SD}[\tilde{a}(S_i)]SD[a~(Si​)]
  5. The simulation result should show that the distribution of ZZZ follows tn−1t_{n-1}tn−1​. Then for p∈(0,1)p\in (0,1)p∈(0,1) we can find a tlowert_{\textrm{lower}}tlower​ and tuppert_\textrm{upper}tupper​ such that

    1−p=P(tlower≤a~(S)−a(P)SD~(a~(S))≤tupper)=P(a~(S)−tupper×SD~[a~(S)]≤μ≤a~−tlower×SD~[a~(S)])\begin{aligned} 1-p &= P\left( t_\textrm{lower}\le \frac{\tilde{a}(S)-a(P)}{\widetilde{SD}(\tilde{a}(S))} \le t_\textrm{upper}\right) \\ &=P\left( \tilde{a}(S)-t_\textrm{upper}\times \widetilde{SD}[\tilde{a}(S)] \le \mu \le \tilde{a} - t_\textrm{lower}\times \widetilde{SD}[\tilde{a}(S)] \right) \end{aligned}1−p​=P(tlower​≤SD(a~(S))a~(S)−a(P)​≤tupper​)=P(a~(S)−tupper​×SD[a~(S)]≤μ≤a~−tlower​×SD[a~(S)])​

    where μ=a(P)\mu=a(P)μ=a(P)
  6. So we can construct the confidence interval, note that since ttt-distribution is symmetric we have tupper=−1×tlower=ct_\textrm{upper}=-1\times t_\textrm{lower}=ctupper​=−1×tlower​=c and we have the confidence interval

    a(S)±c×SD^[a^(S)]a(S)\pm c\times \widehat{SD}[\hat{a}(S)] a(S)±c×SD[a^(S)]

The ttt-distribution approximation of a sampling distribution may work for certain attributes but not all of them. This requires a~(S)\tilde{a}(S)a~(S) to be approximately normal over all possible samples. If a(P)a(P)a(P) is the median or a measure of skewness, we would not expect the ttt-distribution to be a good approximation.

The general approach:

  1. For a given sample SSS, attribute a(S)a(S)a(S) and standard error SD^[a~(S)]\widehat{SD}[\tilde{a}(S)]SD[a~(S)]. Calculate a(S)a(S)a(S) nd SD^[a~(S)]\widehat{SD}[\tilde{a}(S)]SD[a~(S)] based on the sample. Generate BBB bootstrap samples S1∗,…,SB∗S_1^*, \dots, S_B^*S1∗​,…,SB∗​ from SSS with replacement.
  2. For each of the BBB bootstrap samples from above. Calculate a(Sb∗)a(S_b^*)a(Sb∗​) and SD^[a~(Sb∗)],Zb∗=a(Sb∗)−a(S)SD^[a~(Sb∗)]\widehat{SD}[\tilde{a}(S_b^*)], Z_b^*=\frac{a(S_b^*)-a(S)}{\widehat{SD}[\tilde{a}(S_b^*)]}SD[a~(Sb∗​)],Zb∗​=SD[a~(Sb∗​)]a(Sb∗​)−a(S)​
  3. For the values Z1∗,…,ZB∗Z_1^*, \dots, Z_B^*Z1∗​,…,ZB∗​, find clower=QZ(p/2),cupper=QZ(1−p/2)c_\textrm{lower}=Q_Z(p/2), c_{\textrm{upper}}=Q_Z(1-p/2)clower​=QZ​(p/2),cupper​=QZ​(1−p/2), these are quantiles from {Z1∗,…,ZB∗}\left\{ Z_1^*, \dots, Z_B^* \right\}{Z1∗​,…,ZB∗​}
  4. Then a 100(1−p)%100(1-p)\%100(1−p)% bootstrap-ttt confidence interval is

    ((a(S)−cupper×SD^[a~(S)],a(S)−clower×SD^[a~(S)])\left((a(S)-c_\textrm{upper}\times\widehat{SD}[\tilde{a}(S)],a(S)-c_{\textrm{lower}}\times\widehat{SD}[\tilde{a}(S)] \right) ((a(S)−cupper​×SD[a~(S)],a(S)−clower​×SD[a~(S)])

    Note the signs and positions of the constants clower,cupperc_{\textrm{lower}},c_{\textrm{upper}}clower​,cupper​ are in the interval definition.

This method requires an analytic form to calculate SD^[a~(S)]\widehat{SD}[\tilde{a}(S)]SD[a~(S)] i.e. the standard deviation of the estimator given a single sample. Another interval can be constructed using the bootstrap estimate of the standard error SD^∗(a~(S))\widehat{SD}_*(\tilde{a}(S))SD∗​(a~(S)). When the bootstrap is used to calculate SD^∗(a~(Sb∗))\widehat{SD}_*(\tilde{a}(S_b^*))SD∗​(a~(Sb∗​)). This is called the double bootstrap.

4.4.2c The Double Bootstrap

When a(S)=yˉa(S)=\bar{y}a(S)=yˉ​ we have an analytic form for its standard deviation: SD(a~(S))=SD[Y‾]=σn×N−nN−1SD(\tilde{a}(S))=SD[\overline{Y}]=\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}\times \sqrt{\frac{N-n}{N-1}}SD(a~(S))=SD[Y]=n​σ​×N−1N−n​​ where replacing σ\sigmaσ by σ^\hat{\sigma}σ^ gives an estimate SD^[Y‾]\widehat{SD}[\overline{Y}]SD[Y] based on the sample values yuy_uyu​ for u∈Su\in Su∈S. More generally, when a(S)a(S)a(S) is a HT estimate we also have an analytic form for SD^[a~(S)]\widehat{SD}[\tilde{a}(S)]SD[a~(S)]. However, very often an analytic solution is not available for SD^[a~(S)]\widehat{SD}[\tilde{a}(S)]SD[a~(S)], in which case an estimate can be obtained by using the bootstrap by generating S1∗,…,SB∗S_1^*, \dots, S_B^*S1∗​,…,SB∗​ and calculate SD^∗[a~(S)]=∑b=1B(a(Sb∗)−aˉ∗)2B−1\widehat{SD}_*[\tilde{a}(S)]=\sqrt{\frac{\sum_{b=1}^B (a(S_b^*)-\bar{a}^*)^2}{B-1}}SD∗​[a~(S)]=B−1∑b=1B​(a(Sb∗​)−aˉ∗)2​​ where aˉ∗=1B∑b=1Ba(Sb∗)\bar{a}^*=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{b=1}^Ba(S_b^*)aˉ∗=B1​∑b=1B​a(Sb∗​). But in the bootstrap-t, we need an estimate of SD[a~(Sb∗)]\textrm{SD}[\tilde{a}(S_b^*)]SD[a~(Sb∗​)] for every bootstrap sample Sb∗S_b^*Sb∗​.

In order to determine SD^[a~(Sb∗)]\widehat{SD}[\tilde{a}(S_b^*)]SD[a~(Sb∗​)] for each bootstrap sample Sb∗S_b^*Sb∗​ we use the double bootstrap. That is, we apply the bootstrap method to each bootstrap sample Sb∗S_b^*Sb∗​. Too apply a bootstrap within a bootstrap for each bootstrap sample Sb∗S_b^*Sb∗​, we generate DDD bootstrap samples S1∗∗,…,SD∗∗S_1^{**},\dots, S_D^{**}S1∗∗​,…,SD∗∗​ each with replacement from a population now defined as P∗∗=Sb∗P^{**}=S_b^*P∗∗=Sb∗​. The standard deviation of the corresponding values {a(S1∗∗),…,a(SD∗∗)}\{a(S_1^{**}),\dots, a(S_D^{**})\}{a(S1∗∗​),…,a(SD∗∗​)} will provide an estimate of SD^∗[a~(Sb∗)]\widehat{SD}_*[\tilde{a}(S_b^*)]SD∗​[a~(Sb∗​)]. This estimate SD^∗[a~(Sb∗)]\widehat{SD}_*[\tilde{a}(S_b^*)]SD∗​[a~(Sb∗​)] is then substituted into The General Approach for bootstrap-t confidence intervals. For every Sb∗S_b^*Sb∗​ we generate DDD double bootstrap sample Sd∗∗S_d^{**}Sd∗∗​, d∈{1,…,D}d\in\{1,\dots, D\}d∈{1,…,D}.

4.4.2d The Percentile Method

The percentile method for bootstrap confidence intervals is the following: for a given sample SSS generate BBB bootstrap samples S1∗,…,SB∗S_1^*, \dots, S_B^*S1∗​,…,SB∗​ by sampling with replacement from the sample SSS.

  1. For the $b$th bootstrap sample b=1,…,Bb=1,\dots, Bb=1,…,B, calculate a(Sb∗)a(S_b^*)a(Sb∗​)
  2. From the values a1,…,aBa_1, \dots, a_Ba1​,…,aB​, find alower=Qa(p/2)a_{\textrm{lower}}=Q_a(p/2)alower​=Qa​(p/2) and aupper=Qa(1−p/2)a_{\textrm{upper}}=Q_a(1-p/2)aupper​=Qa​(1−p/2)
  3. Then the 100(1−p)%100(1-p)\%100(1−p)% confidence interval is simply [alower,aupper][a_{\textrm{lower}},a_\textrm{upper}][alower​,aupper​]
  4. This approach is equivariant to any 1:1 transformation of the attribute, say T(a(P))T(a(P))T(a(P))
    • For an increasing function T(⋅)T(\cdot)T(⋅) the corresponding interval for T(a(P))T(a(P))T(a(P)) is [T(alower),T(aupper)][T(a_\textrm{lower}), T(a_\textrm{upper})][T(alower​),T(aupper​)]
    • For a decreasing function T(⋅)T(\cdot)T(⋅) the corresponding interval for [T(aupper),T(alower)][T(a_\textrm{upper}), T(a_\textrm{lower})][T(aupper​),T(alower​)]

Simplicity is the attraction of this method. This method is transformation equivariant. The coverage probability is often incorrect if the distribution of the estimator is not nearly symmetric.
